title: analysis bridge north koreas secretive border says chinas cold
story: In the middle of a bridge soaring over the Yalu River in northeast China is a white line painted on the ground, flanked by surveillance cameras, traffic lights and a blue sign indicating the destination ahead: North Korea.For now, the crossing in the border city of Dandong remains quiet, though it’s poised to soon become busy with traffic. Workers began conducting safety inspections last week – preparations that suggest the long-delayed New Yalu River Bridge may soon open, allowing official trade to resume between China and North Korea, which closed its borders after the coronavirus outbreak emerged in Wuhan. It was one of the first countries in the world to do so, given concerns its public health system would buckle if mass disease spread.“We’ve been here for a few days already and will probably be here until early June,” an inspector told the  in mid-May. He is on a team of eight that will soon cross to the North Korean side to examine the bridge, though officials from both sides are still negotiating terms. China has reaffirmed its alliances with nations including North Korea and Russia after the US began pursuing more multilateral engagement. Under President Joe Biden, the US has ramped up efforts to court Asian allies, including Japan and South Korea, in efforts to bolster cooperation on the North Korean nuclear threat and China’s growing influence. On Friday, Mr Biden will welcome South Korean President Moon Jae-in to Washington for an official visit. The meeting could shed light on the US approach, as the Biden administration has been reviewing how to deal with North Korea – with more sanctions, summits or both. The visit also comes as ties between Washington and Beijing have frayed, potentially making China less inclined to collaborate on dealing with North Korea – even though its leaders are concerned about the nuclear threat. China’s ties to the North helped to blunt the impact of United Nations sanctions meant to deter Kim Jong-un’s nuclear ambitions. Smuggling routes and legal trade along the 880-mile border supplied North Korean markets and factories with building materials, machine parts, fuel, food and consumer goods. But the North’s decision to seal its border over coronavirus concerns has been crippling. From January 2020 through the first quarter of this year, China’s official trade with North Korea crashed to $550 million (£400 million), compared to $2.8 trillion in 2019. Chinese exports to North Korea dropped to $3,000 in February, the lowest in years. “Clearly the situation inside, in North Korea, is dire, so it stands to reason we’re at a point that some relaxation (of the border closure) might happen,” said Scott Snyder, senior fellow for Korea Studies at the US-based Council on Foreign Relations. Re-opening trade with China could also indicate that North Korea may ramp up weapons testing again, after a relatively quieter period during the coronavirus pandemic. ”They’re not testing not because they’ve had a change of heart, but because they’re dealing with domestic crises,” said John Park, director of the Korea Project at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government. “They hit the pause button, and if they stabilise and are going to open up bits of trade, that’s a sign they’ve figured out a way to manage this.”Then, “does that mean they take their fingers off the pause button? Does that mean they go back to doing what they said they were going to do before Covid, and that was to demonstrate more potent capabilities?”North Korea has recently again started using shows of force, firing off two short-range ballistic missiles in March – its first such launches in a year, and in defiance of UN Security Council bans on ballistic missile tests. Rumours among traders in Dandong on when border crossings might be allowed again range from next month to early next year. Exactly when depends on the North’s risk appetite with coronavirus. Officially, Pyongyang has told the World Health Organisation that it has had zero cases, though experts doubt the veracity of its claims. Either way, there are signs in the city – spliced from the hermit kingdom by the Yalu River, lined with watchtowers and border guards with guns and masks – that China is laying the groundwork for trading with North Korea.The government of Liaoning province, where Dandong is located, invited bids in March for the safety inspection the  found was underway. Official procurement documents said that the New Yalu River Bridge – a three-kilometre stretch connecting China to North Korea – was “about to be put into operation.Another tender notice, also from March, sought contractors to build a cargo inspection area, logistics warehouse and other facilities to support port operations on the Chinese side of the bridge. Many in Dandong are eager for the border to re-open and activity to resume. Three street vendors told the  that they were running out of smuggled North Korean cigarettes to sell. Few restaurants stock Taedonggang, a beer produced by a state-owned North Korean brewery.Shopkeepers, desperate to make a sale, are quick to offer discounts to passersby – soaps, perfumes, noodles, handbags, and vitamins that North Koreans going back and forth used to buy. An elderly woman who tailors traditional Korean robes was praying in her shop one morning for customers to return.Before the border closure, North Koreans would place large orders for colourful outfits ranging from 170 yuan (£20) for children to 3,600 yuan (£400) for high-end women’s dresses. But these days she’s lucky to sell smaller textiles, such as makeup pouches for 10 yuan (£1.10) each, to Chinese tourists. “Business has been terrible,” she said, making it difficult to cover her monthly shop rent of 3,000 yuan (£330). “I hope the border opens soon.”  More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: beano replace character fatty freddy stop children using name
story: It is Britain’s longest-running children’s comic which brought to life enduring characters such as Dennis the Menace and Minnie the Minx.However, The Beano has now decided to stop using the name of one of its most popular personalities to avoid offending young readers.From this week's issue (number 4087), the character Frederick Brown will no longer be referred to as 'Fatty in The Bash Street Kids comic strip.Instead he will exclusively be called Freddy - or perhaps Frederick if he is being told off by his mother.The creators made the change 67 years after the character was first introduced in a bid to ensure fans are not upset if they are overweight, or to inadvertently encourage youngsters to poke fun at their peers who struggle with their weight.Mike Stirling, editorial director of Beano Studios, said: Kids come in all shapes and sizes, and we absolutely celebrate that. We don't want to risk someone using it in a mean way. The time is right to revert back to Freddy.“We've recently received a number of letters from kids asking us why Frederick Brown was called Fatty, by himself and his classmates. Although it's always been used affectionately, and never pejoratively, we agreed it's time it changed. Freddy's mum - and teacher - may still sometimes address him as 'Frederick', whenever he's in trouble, which for a Bash Street Kid is not uncommon.Much like in 1954, when The Bash Street Kids were created based upon the hilarious antics spotted in the school yard outside of the Beano office, kids are still the inspiration for our characters and storylines and it's incredibly important to us that they see themselves and their lives reflected in Beanotown.”Run by Dundee-based publishing house DC Thomson since 1938, The Beano and its stablemate The Dandy are among the few surviving relics of Britain’s post-war comics boom.The Bash Street Kids characters in The Beano, illustrated by David Sutherland, are notoriously unruly nine-year-old pupils at Bash Street School. Fatty appears alongside Spotty, Danny, Toots, Sidney, Plug, ‘Erbert, Wilfrid and Smiffy.He is drawn as a morbidly obese, balding boy who carries around a bag of cakes. His prized possession is an apron signed by veteran television chef Mary Berry and his motto is 'Everything is delicious', according to his character profile.Mr Stirling insisted that Freddy will still be drawn in the same way, and won't be depicted thinner.All the characters overindulge at times, and Freddy is no different, he said.The Beano's move received a mixed reaction, with some arguing it was overzealous to drop the name Fatty and questioning how much of a role the comic could have really played in encouraging children to use the term as an insult for their overweight peers.Jacob Rees-Mogg, MP and Leader of the House of Commons, said: I expect it is just publicity seeking - otherwise it is comically woke.Others said it was a positive step, with one parent claiming the name had always jarred with her nine-year-old.Debbie Watson, founder of the eating disorder charity Wednesday’s Child, said it was helpful for popular publications to reflect on the message sent out by their content.“Any move which makes creators of literary, visual or social content consider how they are potentially impacting the self-esteem and mental wellbeing of their audience can only be seen as a good thing, she said.While we would never say that an eating disorder is solely caused by derogatory comments about a person’s size, it’s absolutely true that many adults we help, and indeed children, have found themselves triggered into developing poor relationships with food in a bid to escape the cruel labels they received.It seems only right that long-running publications like The Beano should want to reflect on what their characters are called, what message that sends, and whether it is appropriate for the kind of narrative we would want all young people to be using when talking about their friends or classmates.There is an opportunity in this move by the comic to ensure that they rethink not only the name of the character, but also how the storylines reflect the shape and size of all those who are part of The Bash Street Kids, because, as an eating disorder organisation, we continually feel the need to reiterate the message that people of all sizes and shapes can have a devastating eating disorder.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: binmen union submits emergency motion support suspended batley
story: When a teacher was suspended from his school after showing a picture of the Prophet Mohammed in class, he reportedly felt as though he had been “thrown under a bus”.The National Education Union (NEU), was accused of failing to stand up for its own member after it did not immediately condemn the threats of violence and intimidation he faced in the wake of the row.But now, the Batley Grammar School religious studies teacher has found unlikely support from a Bury branch of Unite, which largely represents binmen.Brian Bamford, secretary of Tameside Trade Union Council, has submitted an emergency motion for the National Conference of Trade Union Councils in June to champion the cause of the suspended teacher.The motion urges the NEU and all other unions to support the teacher and to publicly condemn those demanding his dismissal.It notes that blasphemy laws were abolished more than a decade ago, and adds that “dogmatic restraints” should not be imposed on the religious education  curriculum.Mr Bamford is also secretary of Bury Unite commercial branch in the North West, which represents binmen across the borough, and the motion’s wording had to be approved by the branch committee before being passed up to the Tameside TUC which it is affiliated to.This is a motion which has come in from bin men, from ordinary working people, said Mr Bamford, a retired electrician who has been active in the trade union movement since the 1970s.“As far as I can see, staying silent goes contrary to what we believe in at our branch, and especially in the trade congress.“We are affiliated to the Orwell Society and freedom of expression is very important. I don’t feel guilty in any way for taking a stand on this issue.”Mr Bamford claimed that an NEU official attempted to pressurise him into withdrawing the motion on the basis that it was “unhelpful” to draw further attention to the issue.He said he was phoned by the official who asked him to reconsider the motion since it risks inflaming what is an extremely sensitive and very complex situation for members.Mr Bamford was told that the NEU has an obligation to the “wider community in Batley and that any further attention on the matter would set back quite sensitive negotiations.But he said he has no intention of abandoning the motion, adding that the school curriculum should not be “dictated by an indignant mob” who congregated outside Batley Grammar School just before the Easter break.“We are troubled that a teacher can be suspended following protests about his teaching methods and use of materials,” Mr Bamford said.“We are outraged that the teachers involved are being challenged for trying to broaden their students' horizons and encourage their critical thought.“We don't believe that the determination of the use of teaching resources in a school should be influenced by people taking offence, and using intimidation and threats.”Batley Grammar School sent pupils home early for the Easter holidays and issued an apology after a group of Muslims gathered at the gates to protest. The headmaster announced that the religious studies teacher had been suspended while the school looked into what happened.The 29-year-old teacher and his family went into hiding after reportedly receiving death threats in the wake of the protests. The academy trust that runs Batley Grammar School announced at the end of March that it would carry out an “independent” investigation into the context in which the cartoon was shown.A by-election has been triggered in Batley after Tracy Brabin stepped down as MP when she was elected as West Yorkshire's first metro mayor.Ms Brabin, 60, replaced Jo Cox as Batley and Spen MP in a by-election in 2016 after Ms Cox was murdered by a far-right extremist. The seat will be seen as a key test for Labour after the party lost the Hartlepool by-election to the Conservatives earlier this month.An NEU spokesperson said: It is a sensitive issue and the NEU did ask for the motion to be withdrawn. With every viewpoint that is expressed our members face yet more public exposure.They added that speculation is unhelpful, not least for our members who the NEU are fully supporting throughout this investigation and will be doing so beyond the investigation. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: gps roles might evolving bma isnt helping acting like doesnt
story: In the current row over face-to-face appointments at GP surgeries, the NHS authorities are right to say that GPs should offer face-to-face appointments. The concerns of patients as reported in the  and other newspapers are real. General practice cannot command public confidence if there is a perception that face-to-face appointments are not available for people who need them.During the early waves of the pandemic, it was essential for GPs to make a concerted shift to telephone consultations. Without that, they would have been able to deliver only a fraction of their normal service. If a variant of the disease again threatens to overwhelm health services, then telephone consultations will again play an essential role. But when the level of threat is lower, face-to-face appointments must be part of the offer. As Professor Nick Bosanquet of Imperial College London has said, part of the new system could be to offer a telephone line which is always available for urgent calls.However, GPs may be right to feel unhappy that their extraordinary work during the pandemic seems to have been forgotten. As the official data shows, face-to-face appointments have been available in every area of the country and in every month since the pandemic started. In only three months – April, May and June 2020, at the height of the first wave – were there more telephone appointments than face-to-face, and even then the figures were almost equal. On the most recent figures for March this year, there were nearly 16 million face-to-face appointments against 12.5 million appointments of other kinds.GPs deserve huge praise for maintaining their service under the greatest possible pressure. They can build on their excellent work in identifying patients in need of shielding. They likely deserve better than the letter from the NHS authorities that sparked this row, which gave the impression that GPs could not be trusted to make the right decisions on behalf of their patients. It is that unwarranted charge that has caused anger in the profession.That said, there is still certainly no need for the BMA to pass a “vote of no confidence” in NHS leaders, as the  reported today. The situation needs defusing, not throwing more fuel on the fire.When the dust settles, the important question is the style of GP service that the profession takes forward. The following principles may help.First, a recognition that all types of appointments are essential. Face-to-face appointments are needed in many situations, for example to enable GPs to become acquainted with new patients and spend time with those with serious conditions. Equally many patients will prefer telephone consultations.Online forms are an excellent way both to provide information to a surgery and to receive information when it is not time-critical. At the same time, according to recent studies, 10 per cent of the population do not have online access and 25 per cent are not fully comfortable online.  Practices need to provide a telephone service as well as offering online forms.This is why the BMA – the doctors’ representative organisation – is not helping. It is going to take time, hard work and tolerance to work out the right mix between face, telephone and digital. This is a new situation and certainly GPs need to consult with patients. That conversation is much better done locally.Second, general practice can evolve beyond the ten-minute GP consultation. Patients should expect to see practice staff, such as specialist nurses and physiotherapists. That will free up GPs to take longer consultations and get full value for their clinical expertise. In March, staff other than GPs took 45 per cent of all general practice appointments. That figure should rise in coming years.Third, changes at GP surgeries are far from the only way in which the NHS will change visibly in the next ten years. Patients will find themselves going to GP surgeries and other local centres for diagnostic scans rather than going to hospital. We will spend more much time talking to GPs and their staff about our lifestyles. While the Prime Minister speaks of 40 new hospitals, actually the focus will be on creating new local health centres in most English towns.It will be a new NHS offering easier access to services and at a sustainable cost. But it will be a real change, and it will need excellent, even-tempered communication from both Government and professions to provide reassurance to patients and the public.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: latest conflict israel palestine had one winner iran
story: The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, boasts the Israeli Army has won its greatest victory. Hamas’s leader, Ismail Haniya, insists God has granted “defiant Gaza” victory. But who really won the war?Stepping back to look at the broader map of the Middle East, the worrying answer for the West is that it looks likely to be Iran. The ayatollahs’ local surrogates, Hamas, have survived the Israeli onslaught. In the process they have stress-tested the relationship between Israel and its most powerful ally. The cracks that have appeared between Netanyahu’s Israel and Biden’s America will have interested Tehran immensely. President Biden did not exactly abandon his country’s traditional allies. But his demand for an “unconditional ceasefire”, initially resisted by the Israelis, marked a sharp contrast with the usual rock solid support offered to Israel by Washington. US support for Israel’s security interests is shifting as the Biden team unravels the Trump foreign policy legacy. Nowhere was Trump more at odds with his predecessor and his predecessor’s vice-president than over the Middle East. Trump’s approach, of attempting to secure peace in the Middle East not by settling the question of Israel and Palestine but by uniting the region’s major powers around a shared distrust of Iran, led to remarkable results during his tenure. Now, however, the Obama-era orthodoxy has once again taken hold at the State Department. Aware that a “hardliner” is set to win the impending Iranian presidential election, “expert” opinion among Biden’s backers in Washington is that the President should hurry to reverse Trump’s withdrawal from the JCPOA before that happens. The thinking, which many would describe as hopelessly naive given past behaviour, is that this would “lock in” the Islamic Republic to its non-proliferation obligations. It is a good deal for Iran, with sanctions lifted and no restrictions on its research into the ancillary weapons systems necessary for an atomic weapon. What’s more, the restrictions even on enriching uranium, the final piece of the nuclear puzzle, are time-limited, too. Israel’s undeclared war on Iran’s nuclear programme is becoming a lonely one.Sensing Washington’s weakening stance on containing Iran, Saudi Arabia has opened “secret” talks with Tehran. This suggests that the Kingdom, having seen the treatment of Israel, is no longer confident of unequivocal US backing and is seeking to mend its fences with the Islamic Republic. This is a big step backwards from the rapprochement that took place between Israel and the Saudis under President Trump.That could mean Iran will rein in its Houthi allies in Yemen who have been firing missiles Hamas-style into Saudi Arabia, hitting its oil fields. Any ceasefire in Yemen, like in Gaza, will save civilian lives. The danger is that if Iran is the “peace-maker”, it can also be the “peace-breaker” when Tehran judges the moment right to resume conflict.The war between Israel and Gaza will have interested another Iranian proxy, too. Hizbollah in Lebanon did not feel the need to join in this time. But they will have been watching with interest how Israel’s Iron Dome worked against the Hamas rockets. Despite the Israeli Air Force’s repeated efforts to intercept weapons supplies to Hizbollah via Syria, Israel’s northern enemy has built up a much more formidable arsenal than Hamas had put together clandestinely in Gaza.US disengagement from the broader Middle East, including Afghanistan on Iran’s eastern flank, means the Islamic Republic is winning on points in the great game to decide the future of the region. Washington and the West pressured Israel to make peace but Iran will decide if it lasts. Mark Almond is director of the Crisis Research Institute, OxfordMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ufo uap aliens report sightings us government encounters barack
story: She has also had one of the most famous close encounters with a UFO, or Unidentified Flying Object.In separate planes, Lt Cdr Dietrich and Commander David Fravor were dispatched to investigate.What they saw on that day has never been adequately explained – until now.Cmdr Fravor aggressively engaged one of the oblong objects, which he estimated to be 40ft in length, while Lt Cdr Dietrich adopted “high cover” above.Ship radar picked it up seconds later, 60 miles away. A third FA-18 then caught it on an infrared camera: it looked like a giant white Tic Tac.Lt Cdr Dietrich decided to go public with her story now – three years after Cdr Fravor – to reduce the “stigma” associated with UFO reports and, she says, to encourage other pilots to come forward without feeling “embarrassed or ashamed”.Her testimony coincides with a growing acceptance among defence officials around the world that there may indeed be something “out there” – and that it might pose a genuine global security threat.After decades of doing everything possible to keep reported sightings secret, there has been a sea change in how the Pentagon regards such sightings.For starters, it no longer refers to them as UFOs – with their connotations of little green men – but to UAPs, or Unidentified Aerial Phenomena. Next month, Congress is to be given an unclassified report on evidence collected by the Pentagon’s UAP Task Force, the Office of Naval Intelligence and the FBI.Ufologists - people who investigate UFOs - across the globe are hailing it as an unprecedented watershed moment in their long quest to uncover what the US government really knows – and they have former president Donald Trump to thank for it.“We’re absolutely in new territory here,” says Nick Pope, who investigated UFO sightings while working as a British civil servant for the Ministry of Defence in the 1990s.“What’s really elevated this is the sheer number, and position, of people now speaking out, saying we’re dealing with something that must be taken seriously, he added.“When top guns, who don’t impress easily, get excited about the capability of these objects, their speed, manoeuvrability, trans-medium travel in water and air… that gets my attention.The pilot testimony is important, but there is so much more: radar data, infrared, measurement and signature intelligence… and we’ll get to see some of it.”John Ratcliffe, director of National Intelligence under President Trump, raised anticipation when he hinted recently that there was “a lot” more information than the public currently knows.He said he had seen satellite imagery of objects “frankly engaging in actions that are difficult to explain”, and incidents of them breaking the sound barrier with no sonic boom.The following month, a farmer found wreckage on a ranch near Roswell, New Mexico. In a press release, the US military called it a “flying disc”, but later said it was part of a weather balloon.By the 1950s, the US Air Force was being inundated with UFO reports from the public. One of the most notorious was the so-called “Invasion of Washington” in 1952, when numerous sightings were made over the capital in a two-week period.It was the Cold War, and the CIA, fearing mass hysteria could play into the hands of the Soviet Union, worked to debunk sightings and infiltrate UFO-hunting groups.“Further extensive study of UFOs probably cannot be justified,” it said.For decades afterwards, anyone who reported seeing something strange in the sky was considered a crackpot – even leading lights in the US military.However, there remained a few highly influential figures who believed a mystery was there to be solved. The most powerful among them was Senator Harry Reid, the Democrat leader in the US Senate from 2005 to 2017.In 2007, Mr Reid managed to push through Congress, clandestinely, $22 million in “black ops” funding for a new department. It was innocuously named the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP).From a fifth-floor office deep inside the Pentagon, a real-life X-Files team studied hundreds of reported UFO sightings – including the USS Nimitz “Tic Tac” incident from 2004.The department was led by Luis Elizondo, a career intelligence official who later resigned because he felt his findings were not being taken seriously enough.Shortly after his departure in late 2017, Mr Elizondo told the  how his team established geographical “hot spots” for sightings, sometimes near nuclear facilities, and common ways in which UFOs moved.“We began to see trends and similarities in incidents – very distinct observables. Extreme manoeuvrability, hypersonic velocity without a sonic boom, speeds of 8,000mph. A lot of this was supported by radar signal data, gun camera footage from aircraft, multiple witnesses.”He said he came to a “realisation that these are probably not any type of aircraft in any national inventory. I think it’s pretty clear it’s not us. So one has to ask the question where they’re from.”He also added: “There was never any display of hostility.”A key moment in the UFO debate – and whether it should be taken seriously – came in 2017 when the New York Times published the infrared video of the “Tic Tac” sighting. Ufologists felt vindicated, not least because it proved the Pentagon had seen fit to investigate the incident.Today, thanks to lockdown – which provided a dramatic reduction in light pollution coupled with an army of people with empty evenings on their hands – supposed UFO sightings have proliferated around the globe.In the UK alone, reports of suspected alien spacecraft doubled last year.And once-secret intelligence just keeps coming. Last month, footage of bizarre images of flashing pyramid-shaped UFOs was posted online, which the Pentagon confirmed was taken in 2019, by a US Navy ship off California.Another leaked video, taken from a fighter jet in 2015, showed a small object moving at tremendously high speed just above the water off Virginia on the US east coast. Pilots could be heard yelling: “Oh my gosh, dude” and “Wow! What is that, man? Look at that flying!”In another incident, pilots reported seeing an object that looked like a cube inside a sphere flying between their aircraft, which were barely 100ft apart.Many of these incidents are expected to be further detailed in next month’s report. But even though it will be “unclassified”, it's still unclear exactly how much will come out.“I don’t expect it’ll plunge into extraterrestrial visitation. If there is anything really juicy, it will probably be in the classified annex. Governments are just nervous and reluctant to say ‘We don’t know...’ because it makes them look weak and ineffective.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

Ms Sturgeon said the total number of cases in East Renfrewshire is signicantly smaller than in Glasgow, with only  on Thursday compared to  in the city, and could be traced to specic household clusters. Public bodies like the NHS and local councils can put in every measure we like, but without community support they will not make the same dference. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe report into how Martin Bashir secured his interview with Princess Diana marks a shameful day for the BBC. Bashir’s deceitful and unethical behaviour was an abuse of his position and a clear breach of the high journalistic standards on which his former employer prides itself. The BBC then added to the disgrace by failing to investigate properly the underhand tactics used to land the  interview. The whole sorry affair has caused understandable anguish for the late Princess’s family and friends. Earl Spencer has claimed there is a link between the programme and his sister’s death two years later.  The BBC has rightly apologised but its expressions of remorse will count for nothing unless it ensures that such a situation can never happen again. Bashir’s reputation rightly lies in tatters but his personal ignominy should not be allowed to tarnish the whole corporation, which still strives to deliver impartial journalism. Buck passers The Government has set aside £billion for the Covid test and trace system. Despite the eye-watering amount lavished, the programme is still not working properly.  We now learn that technical glitches were partly responsible for the spread of the Indian iant, with councils unable to respond to the outbreak because they could not access the data on positive tests in their area. Yet earlier this week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock implied it was the failure of people to get vaccinated that was behind the surge. This now comes across as an attempt to sht the blame for the Government’s own failings. Instead of trying to pass the buck, ministers should start taking some responsibility. story: NewsMy narcolepsy caused paralysis and hallucinations - but working out gave me my le backEXCLUSIVE: Belle Hutt, , dropped out of school due to bullying after she was diagnosed with narcolepsy. After a tough few years battling the disorder, Belles love of exercise has given her a new lease of lemirrorShareCommentsByJessica Taylor:,  MAY NewsBelle Hutt, a personal trainer and fitness instructor, has lived with narcolepsy since she was  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBelle Hutt was studying for her GCSEs when she began struggling to stay awake in class. Despite getting a full night’s sleep, she was battling with an urge to close her eyes and snooze. “I had no idea what it was, so I’d just get up and go to the loo to wake up. Then I’d come back and be fine,” she told The Mirror. Over time, the bouts of exhaustion became more frequent, until eventually they were happening every day. Things came to a head when Belle was  and something strange happened in a biology exam. “In the middle of the exam I started to write a note out to my dad in perfect handwriting. I didn’t even realise I was doing it,” she explained.  “It was like I was dreaming before I’d even shut my eyes.” Later, Belle went home and told her worried mum, Debbie, what had happened. Meanwhile, she was still having daily sleep attacks and struggling to stay awake during the day. As her th birthday approached, Belle was getting ready to learn how to drive and had taken her theory test in anticipation. But Debbie was concerned. “My Mum wanted me to see a doctor before I got behind the wheel as she wasn’t comfortable with me driving,” Belle said. After seeing her GP, the teen was advised to go to bed earlier and stop looking at her phone late at night. “That didn’t seem right to me - I was already going to bed so early because I was exhausted,” she said.  In time, she was referred to a sleep specialist. After several tests, Belle was diagnosed with severe narcolepsy, a chronic sleep disorder. As the doctors explained the diagnosis, Debbie asked what could be done to cure the condition. “The doctors bluntly said: ‘There’s no cure. It’ll only get worse’,” Belle recalled. As her symptoms worsened, she noticed people making fun of her. “I was always the first to fall asleep at parties so people would draw on my face and do silly things like that. “After a while I stopped going to parties. I didn’t even worry about missing out because I was so exhausted.” In time, the bullying became so bad that Belle decided to leave school. By now, she was having sleep attacks between three and four times a day. Instead of allowing herself to nap, Belle fought the urge to fall asleep. But this brought on hallucinations and cataplexy. Cataplexy, commonly associated with narcolepsy, is a sudden loss of muscle strength triggered by an intense emotion such as laughter.  “It would only last for a few seconds, but sometimes I just wouldn’t be able to talk,” she explained. Perhaps the most frightening symptom Belle experienced was hallucinations when she was wide awake. “I’d be at home alone and I’d hear people open my front door, walk up the stairs and walk into my bedroom. I’d see them looking at me. It was so real,” she told The Mirror. “Because I was so scared, that would trigger cataplexy and I wouldn’t be able to move.” For three years, Belle battled to stay awake through the sleep attacks, trying to keep active instead. Belle said: “I started personal training when I was , I just had a few clients I’d see one-to-one from the gym in our garage. “I felt like I’d never be able to work for anyone  so this was my only option.” Around the same time, she met her now-fiancé, Maikel. After three years of dating, Belle moved to Amsterdam to live with him. “I thought I wouldn’t be able to work and needed someone to look after me,” she said. But eventually, a friend told her about People’s Place Gym in the city, which was looking for fitness class instructors. “I started working there and they were so good about everything. They’d let me take mats and blankets for naps during the dayI needed them.”  After leading a few classes at the gym, Belle realised something. “I felt such an incredible buzz and I was so awake. I realised I could lead three classes a day and fit in naps in between,” she explained.Things were going well until coronavirus raged around the globe and gyms across Europe shut their doors. Instead of sitting around waiting for them to reopen, Belle took matters into her own hands, and began leading live workouts on Instagram every morning.And it’s worked wonders for her narcolepsy symptoms. “I started doing % more exercise than I was before, leading workouts every day,” she said. “Since becoming fitter and stronger, I’ve not suffered from cataplexy for about a year. It’s given me so much more control over my day.” She now runs the @BelleHuttLiveCommunity on Instagram, leading live workouts every day for more than  people who attend her classes.  She also uses her personal account @BelleHutt, which has more than , followers, to dispel common myths about narcolepsy. “People think I just need more sleep than anyone , but actually I find it hard to sleep through the night,” she told the Mirror. “I take medication at night now which helps me sleep for longer, but before that I was getting two hours of broken sleep a night.” She described narcolepsy as having a disrupted body clock, so the body gets confused about when it needs to sleep. Using her  to explain the condition, she also wants to tackle parody depictions of the sleep disorder. “I’ve seen comedy characters who have narcolepsy as people who just fall over and sleep in the middle of the day, and that’s really not what it is,” she explained. After discovering the wonders of regular exercise, Belle wants to inspire people to move their bodies for their own mental wellbeing. “So many people label exercise as for fat loss, but I want people to realise it’s great for your mental health. “You don’t have to be at the gym, or even wearing trainers. You can be dancing around the living room in jeansyou want, but it feels so great to move your body.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPersonal trainerBullyingFitness

story: AdvertorialWhat you can and cant do this weekend under new government Covid rulesRestrictions have eased this week in England, which means emotional reunions for many people – but we still need to follow the rules to protect our loved onesmirrorShareByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialFamilies across England are reuniting as lockdown restrictions ease and indoor hospitality is once again open, including cinemas, pubs and concert venues. It’s the first time since  that people from dferent households have been allowed to meet indoors. Now, they can mix inside in groups of six – or two households – and celebrations such as weddings and christenings in Covid-secure settings are permitted, with up to  people. But the virus is still out there with one in three people showing no symptoms, so regular rapid testing and following the Hands, Face, Space, Fresh Air guidance will help us all stay safe and stop the spread. Meeting outdoors is always the safest option, andyou do go indoors stick to the rule of six or two households. Here’s what you need to know to follow the rules and stay safe... I can’t wait to hug my parents. Is that permitted now   Yes, you can now have close contact with family and friends – including hugs. Use caution and common sense and think about the risk of catching or passing on the virus, which spreads mainly among people who are in close contact . I’d love a minibreak. Can I stay overnight with friends now  Yes. Hotels, BBs and hostels are now open, so overnight stays are permitted for groups of up to six, or two households. I’m sick of doing yoga on Zoom – can I go to a class in person   Yes, organised exercise classes, including those in gyms or yoga and Pilates can resume in a Covid-safe environment. Can I go to the cinema now  Yes. Indoor attractions and hospitality venues are open, including cinemas, restaurants, museums, theatres, bowling alleys and organised indoor sporting events. My nan’s in a care home. How many visitors can she have   Care home residents can have up to five regular visitors, with up to two at one time or in a single day . Residents can now leave the home for a low-risk visit, such as a walk in the park, without then having to self-isolate for  days. I’m still unsure about mixing indoors. How can I stay safe  Go at your own pace and follow the rules. It’s safer to meet outsideyou can – and minimise close contact. If you do choose to meet indoors, open a window to ventilate and let fresh air in. Remember, some people are more vulnerable than others and exercise caution at all times. One in three people who have Covid- shows no symptoms, so get into a routine of taking two tests a week and isolatethe result is positive. Maintain a two-metre distance and wear a face covering whenever you’re out in public.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA drink-driver ran over a young boy and trapped him underneath his car before ignoring witnesses - and reversing back over the child. The victim, , was cycling in West Chiltington, West Sussex with his father when he was struck from behind by a Renault Twingo. Keith Vernon, , was at the wheel of the vehicle - which knocked the youngster over his handlebars and into the road. The motorist then continued to drive over the boy, police say, despite the desperate warnings of horried onlookers. Vernon ignored the pleas of the members of the public and reversed over the boy, seriously injuring him and destroying his helmet.Have you been affected by this incident  Email webnews@mirror. He then fled the scene with the bike still trapped beneath his car, it was said. Shocking pictures show the mangled remains of the car, the helmet and the bike. Emergency services raced to the incident, which occurred about .pm on October , and the boy was taken to hospital. He suffered a broken collar bone, a fractured vertebrae, a fractured pelvis, a dislocated hip and a burn covering the left side of his face. Sussex Police say he is now recovering. The force attended the address of the registered owner of the Twingo, which was discovered unattended and having mounted a kerb, with the victim’s bike still trapped beneath. Retired Vernon, of West Chiltington, was then breathalysed and found to have mcg of alcohol per ml of breath in his system. The legal limit is mcg.  He was subsequently arrested and charged with causing serious injury by dangerous driving, drink-driving and failing to stop after a road traffic collision. He pleaded guilty to the offences at Worthing magistrates’ court on February  and before appearing for sentencing at Hove crown court on May . There he was jailed for two-and-a-half years’ imprisonment and was disqualied from driving for four-and-a-half years. His sentence was reduced for his early guilty plea. Her Honour Judge Barnes said Vernon deliberately made a conscious decision to drive when drunk. She did not accept that he had not seen the cyclists, and added that he had a desire to protect himself before anyone . The judge said she did not accept that Vernon did not know the child was under his car She also commented how any father could put himself over a child was beyond belief. She added that Vernon made the decision to go home, despite stating he was traumatised, and made no attempt to call  orto the scene. The judge also said there is no blame whatsoever to be put on the cyclists. Sergeant Richard Hornsey, formerly of the Serious Collision Investigations Unit, said: Vernon was driving home after drinking in a local pub and was over the drink-drive limit when he collided with the cyclist. This was clearly a traumatic incident for those directly involved, but it has also affected the wider community. Vernon ignored the pleas of the bystanders, which included the child’s father, and they described the wheels of the car spinning as Vernon tried to drive away while the child and the bicycle were trapped underneath. The child was wearing a cycle helmet which received signicant damage but protected him from a more serious head injury. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTwo metal detectorists are celebrating after a ‘nationally important’ Roman bronze hoard of artefacts they dug up sold for £,. James Spark and Mark Didlick uncovered the bust of emperor Marcus Aurelius last year alongside a statuette of the god of Mars on horseback, a horse-head kne handle and a large bronze pendulum. The immaculately preserved items were buried in a field in Ryedale, North Yorks, as an offering to the gods as part of a Roman religious ceremony in about AD. The finely-modelled bust of the Roman ruler Marcus Aurelius, who ruled from -AD, depicts him with hair and beard flamboyantly curled. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  It would have been attached to the end of a sceptre which probably belonged to a senior military commander about , years ago. Found alongside it was the toy-like god of Mars on horseback, the decorative end of a kne and a plumb-bob- a weight that acted like a spirit-level used by the Romans in construction. The antiquities were found over a one square metre area in a field. It was initially thought the four objects might be worth about £, in total.  But the auction house that sold them increased their estimate to £, after receiving worldwide interest ahead of the sale. The objects sold for a hammer price of £, with Hansons Auctioneers, of Etwall, Derbys, following a bidding war. The winning bidder, a London buyer who was in the room, paid £, including fees. On the rostrum, auctioneer Charles Hanson said: “It was an extraordinary result for an extraordinary lot.  “It was an honour to auction these fascinating historical items - antiquities which had not seen been for , years. “This was a lot like no other. It provided a tantalising insight into Roman le centuries ago.” Adam Staples, Hansons historica expert, said: “I’m thrilled for the finders and landowner who watched the auction. “It was a fantastic result.”  He added: “The hoard of artefacts was probably buried as a religious offering which marked the closure of a rural shrine or the death of a priest. “The artefacts would have formed a suite of ritual implements, to be utilised when performing religious ceremonies and for predicting the future. “Heis indeed very lucky not to have been broken by his , years spent underground.  “The bust has survived extremely well and is in very fine condition with a glossy green patina. “This is a nationally important group of artefacts.” Mr Spark, , from York, previously described the moment he and Mr Didlick found the hoard. He said: “We were having a pretty slow day when, as we were just about to pack up, I came across a strong signal. title: mum 30 begs judge mercy
story: NewsMum, , begs judge for mercy and not to be jailed like her two killer ex-boyfriendsSarah Clarke was jailed for  months after being convicted of assisting murderer Stephen Strutt, who was jailed for killing Warren Glover in St Helens, MerseysidemirrorShareByNeil Docking:,  MAY NewsSarah Clarke was jailed for  months after being found guilty of assisting an offender " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum who helped her killer partner evade police today begged a judge for mercy for the sake of her little boy. Sarah Clarke, , is the ex of two men serving le for murder - her eight-year-old sonaposs dad and stepdad.Her childaposs father, Damian aposScarfaceapos Gorman, was jailed for a pub assassination with notorious cop killer Dale Cregan, the Liverpool Echo reports.Her sonaposs stepdad, Stephen Strutt, was one of four killers who murdered dad-of-one Warren Glover. Clarke told police deliberate lies about his whereabouts, later hiding him in a Blackpool hotel room, booked using her auntaposs bank card. Clarke sobbed as her lawyer today made a plea for mercy at Liverpool Crown Court. He said this was for her son, for whom she is the sole carer.  But Judge Denis Watson, QC, said her case was yet another example of how a criminalaposs actions impact on not only the lives of their victims, but their own family as well.CCTV footage showed Strutt, , stopping to buy beer when he travelled from Manchester to Merseyside with a gang to hunt down Mr Glover on Saturday, June  last year.Judge Watson said the victim was killed out of vengeance, after sending offensive and provocative texts to his ex-girlfriend Melissa Stubbs, , her parents and friends.The NHS worker was attacked by Melissaaposs brother Aaron Stubbs, , in residential French Street, at around .pm.Aaron and Melissa earlier threatened they were coming to smack his head in and their mum Gail Duff had texted the victim: Prepare to meet your maker. Mr Glover came out with a lump hammer and damaged the Stubbsapos car, before running away, but Aaron struck him over the head from behind with an iron bar.  Strutt had recruited his brother-in-law, Peter Walker, , to join the attack, who chased Mr Glover with a baseball bat. Mr Glover was found unconscious in the street and died in hospital on July .Aaron, Melissa, Strutt and Walker were all found guilty of murder after a trial, when Clarke was convicted of assisting an offender.Strutt, who had a child of his own, lived with Clarke in Stalybridge, but she claimed she had no idea he was wanted for murder. Judge Watson said when Struttaposs family home was searched by police on July , Clarke texted her sister details from the search documents. On July , she sent a text to Strutt saying donapost get caught with him, which Judge Watson said was a reference to Aaron Stubbs, then still at large.  He told Clarke from at least July  and likely earlier, you knew perfectly well that the police were wanting to speak to your partner and from that date onwards at the very latest you knew he was wanted for questioning in relation to a murder investigation. The judge said she searched online about who was going to be charged and knew from seeing Struttaposs photo that he was wanted, but all the while you provided shelter and advice for him. Judge Watson told her that was serious enough, but you then actively misled the police to his whereabouts, telling them that he not been seen by you for several days and that he was working away. The judge, who branded these deliberate lies, said the next day the couple travelled to Garstang, where she persuaded relatives to let her use their bank cards to book a hotel in a dferent name in Blackpool. The court heard they stayed overnight there, but police by then had tracked down and arrested Strutt. Andy Scott, defending, said character references from family and friends spoke in the most positive and glowing terms of Ms Clarke, her qualities as a mother and as a friend.  He said: Sarah Clarke of course is anxious over her fate. However, she acknowledges that her anxiety, her distress, is nothing compared with the grief and trauma of the family and friends of Warren Glover. Pleading for mercy, he said she had a realistic prospect of rehabilitation, strong personal mitigation and jailing her would have a signicant harmful impact on her child. He said Clarke was considered a low risk of reconviction and a medium risk of causing danger to the public, and her only past conviction was for motoring offences last year. Mr Scott suggested her crime didnapost extensively impede justice and when hiding Strutt in Blackpool, it was inevitable she would have ed home, because of her son. Judge Watson interjected: She might have done. Mr Scott said Strutt was arrested within hours of them going to the hotel and asked the judge to balance that with texts she sent him asking himself to hand himself in. Clarke cried in the dock as Mr Scott added: She is of course a sole carer for her son, Of course we know that Mr Strutt was the stepfather. He had been taken away. Ms Clarke has ended that relationship with Mr Strutt.  He said Clarke feared her relationship with her son would be irreparably damaged and the rupture to it enormous, adding thatshe was jailed, it would be devastating. Mr Scott said: She will lose her liberty. She will also lose her home. He said the eight-year-old boy had dficulties of his own, outlined at a recent Child in Need meeting, but he would not delve into further personal matters in a report. Mr Scott said: To say Ms Clarke has been unlucky in love is an understatement. Once again, ultimately she will have to pick up the fragments of a fractured relationship. She takes the blame heavily on her own shoulders. That again primarily is because of the harm and the hurt she will have caused her son. The judge said he had bore the impact on her son in mind, but her crime was a real, albeit short lived impediment to an arrest police had tried to make for weeks. Judge Watson, who said the signicant mitigation had resulted in a shorter sentence, jailed Clarke for  months. One of Clarkeaposs supporters - a man sitting in the public gallery - stood up and shouted you will be alright as she was sent down, while a sobbing woman rushed towards the dock and said: Can we see her  Judge Watson said: You wonapost be able to see her - thank you very much for coming. The man moaned smug face on him as he stormed out of court. Jailing Strutt for le with a minimum of  years, Judge Watson previously said: You knew you were wanted by the police and you were trying to lie low in Blackpool to avoid arrest. Aaron Stubbs, of Lane End Road, Burnage, was jailed for le with a minimum of  and a half years. Melissa Stubbs, of the same address as her brother, was jailed for le with a minimum of  and a half years. Walker, of Garth Road, Wythenshawe, was jailed for le with a minimum of  and a half years. Clarkeaposs ex-boyfriend Gorman was convicted of the murder of gangland rival Mark Short, and the attempted murder of three other men, at an east Manchester pub. Clarkeaposs relationship with Gorman led to her facing a charge of intimidating a witness and giving evidence at his and Creganaposs murder trial in . Preston Crown Court heard Clarke and Gorman lived together for three years and she had his son in September . The then -year-old told the trial she had been charged with intimidating a female witness, who had given evidence against Gorman, then . She denied intimidating the woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons, in a park following the midnight shooting of Mark Short in May . That witness described how intimidating cocaine dealer Gorman, who she said was known as Scarface, had threatened her thatshe went to the police, the one-eyed Scotchman - Cregan - would kill her. The prosecution alleged the two assassins Cregan and Gorman went to clean up at Clarkeaposs home after killing Mark Short and pointed to Gormanaposs clothing, found outside the property in bin bags, as evidence of this. However, Clarke told jurors she had dumped Gormanaposs clothes outside the house they rented in Hollingworth, Tameside, when she moved out because Gorman had been jailed for  weeks over a previous matter. The animal group which led the original pet killing investigation - SNARL - is looking into the slaying which they believe is linked to the Croydon Cat Killer. Katherine, a student beautician from Catford, Lewisham, said: Iaposd be able to managehe had died in a normal way, but this is really disturbing. I would hate for anybody  to go through the same pain. This killer has to be found. politan Police spent over £, and , hours during their investigation into the cat deaths, but in  they ruled the serial cat killer did not exist and the mutilations were caused by foxes. No evidence of human involvement was found in any of the reported cases and there was no CCTV footage, identiable patterns, forensic leads or witnesses. CCTV footage that was recovered showed foxes carrying bodies or body parts of cats.  Tony Jenkins, founder of South Norwood Animal Rescue and Liberty, collected the pet, and then contacted Katherine as he had heard about her search for Theo. The heartbroken cat owner identied her cat from photos, due to his distinctive markings. The woman then called the police and said they were kind to her, but could not look into Theoaposs death due to a lack of CCTV and because the investigation had closed. She said: When Tony called back my heart just sank. Tony said the way Theo was killed and the fact that his head and tale were missing linked Theo to the Croydon Cat Killer. He said: The conclusion of the investigation doesnapost explain why these are predominantly happening in the southeast of England but we have cars and foxes over the whole of the UK. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Harry has revealed he suffered panic attacks and descended into binge drinking and drugs while battling feelings of being unable to save his mother. The Duke of Sussex opened up in his new Apple TV+ show about the trauma he suffered following Princess Diana’s death in a car crash in . But while speaking to Oprah Winfrey, he launched yet another broadside at his family, revealing he was “worried and afraid” toto the UK for Prince Philip ’s funeral. Speaking to the US chat show queen in the five-part series The Me You Can’t See, the Prince, , also told how we Meghan urged him seek help more than four years ago following a fight where he reverted to a “-year-old”. The series shows him having therapy such as EMDR treatment, an interactive psychotherapy technique used to relieve trauma and PTSD.  Harry tells how he first tried to seek help for his mental health in his s after years of pain before finally committing to therapy when he met Meghan, now , five years ago. The Duke said of emotional turmoil in his childhood and s: “I wasn’t in an environment where it was encouraged to talk about it either, that was sort of, like, squashed.” The series is another chapter in the unprecedented openness Harry is bringing to his le since stepping away from his royal duties and moving to Calornia with pregnant Meghan and their son Archie, two. Since March, he and Meghan have accused the Royal Family of racism and cutting them off financially.  Astonishingly, while on the series, Harry claimed he and Meghan believed their explosive interview with Winfrey would actually help reconcile them with the royals. However, their accusations have reportedly driven a deep wedge between the Duke and his brother, Prince William. Harry described the bombshell discussion as “real and authentic”. He said: “I like to think that we were able to speak truths in the most compassionate way possible, therefore leaving an opening for reconciliation and healing.” He added of Meghan: “Before the Oprah interview had aired, because of the combined efforts of The Firm and the media to smear her, I was woken up in the middle of the night to her crying into her pillow because she doesn’t want to wake me up because I’m already carrying too much. That’s heartbreaking.” On Diana  Harry again hinted racism played a part in his le saying his mother was “chased to death while in a relationship with someone who wasn’t white”. He added he feared “history repeating itself” with we Meghan. The Princess of Wales died in  alongside Egyptian film producer Dodi Al-Fayed, who she had been dating for several months. “My mother was chased to her death while she was in a relationship with someone who wasn’t white,” he said. “And now look what’s happened. “You want to talk about history repeating itself. They’re not going to stop until she dies. “It’s incredibly triggering to potentially lose another woman in my le. Like, the list is growing.”  Talking about his struggles, Harry said he was still “haunted” by the sound of horses hooves down The Mall at his mother’s funeral. He said he was “outside of his body” while following the coffin. “When my mum was taken away from me at the age of , just before my th birthday, I didn’t want the [royal] le. Sharing the grief of my mother’s death with the world,” he revealed. Harry said he believes his late mother ‘helped him get where he is today and that he’s “never felt her presence more” than he has over the last year living in Calornia with his family. He added: “I’m living the le that she wanted to live for herself. Living the le that she wanted us to be able to live.” On drink and drug abuse  The Prince opened about his past use of drink and drugs, saying the trauma of his mother’s death left him seeking a release. He said he used them both to “mask” his hurt to “feel less like I was feeling”. The father of one, who is expecting his second child - a daughter - later this summer, told Winfrey he would consume a week’s worth of alcohol on a Friday or Saturday night “not because I was enjoying it but because I was trying to mask something”. In the first episode, he tells the American chat-show host about the years following the death of his mother. Harry said: “I was willing to drink, I was willing to take drugs, I was willing to do the things that made me feel less like I was feeling. “But I slowly became aware that, okay I wasn’t drinking Monday to Friday, but I would probably drink a week’s worth in one day on a Friday or a Saturday night.”  He said he found his brain was “telling [him] that I’m in a fight”. Harry described the ages “ to ” as a “nightmare”. The Prince said: “Every time I put a suit on and tie on ... having to do the role, and go, ‘right, game face, look in the mirror and say, “let’s go”. Before I even left the house, I was pouring with sweat. I was in fight or flight mode. “From freaking out every single time I jumped in the car and every single time I see a camera - I would just start sweating. “I would feel as though my body temperature was two or three degrees warmer than everybody  in the room. I would convince myself that my face was bright red and therefore, everybody could see how I was feeling, but no one would know why, so that was embarrassing.” Attack on royal family  The Duke of Sussex detonated a “truth bomb” on his own family, accusing them of “total silence” and “neglect” when Meghan was suicidal. He claimed his father, Prince Charles, made him “suffer” as a child insisting he would no longer be “bullied into silence” when he alleged royal le “trapped” and then dumped them. “Certainly now I will never be bullied into silence,” he told Winfrey. “I thought my family would help, but every single ask, request, warning, whatever it is, just got met with total silence, total neglect. “We spent four years trying to make it work. We did everything that we possibly could to stay there and carry on doing the role and doing the job. But Meghan was struggling.” He went on: “That feeling of being trapped within the family, there was no option to leave. “Eventually, when I made that decision for my family, I was still told, ‘You can’t do this’. And it’s like, ‘Well how bad does it have to get until I am allowed to do this ’. “She [Meghan] was going to end her le. It shouldn’t have to get to that.” On royal le  Harry is seen to complain about his royal le during the series, saying it was becoming his family’s “yes man” that led to him suffering severe fatigue. During the series second episode, he said he was “forced” into trips singling out his visit to Nepal in  and became his le became “really hectic but to the point of exhaustion”. The Duke said: “Towards my late s, everything became really hectic for me, but to the point of exhaustion. “I was travelling all over the place because, you know, from the family’s perspective, I guess I was the person who [was] like ‘we need someone to go there. Nepal, Harry you go’.  “I was always the yes man I was always the one willing to say yes. But that yes and yes and yes, of course, yes yes yes led to burnout. “And it was like someone had taken the lid off. All of the emotions that I had suppressed for so many years suddenly came to the forefront.” He then described how his burnout led to him seeing medical help and that only on meeting Meghan did it save him. He said: “I saw GPs, I saw doctors, I saw therapists, I saw alternative therapists, I saw all sorts of people. “But it was meeting and being with Meghan - I knew thatI didn’t do therapy and fix myself, that I was going to lose this woman who I could see spending the rest of my le with.” On his row with Meghan  Harry told Winfrey how a row with then-girlfriend Meghan Markle was what led to the therapy he needed. After an explosive row, he said she turned to him and said: “I think you need to see someone.” He told how it “was in reaction to an argument that we had. And in that argument, not knowing about it, I reverted back to -year-old Harry.” Before getting the help he needed, the Prince said he would try to push the trauma from his mother’s death to one side. “I don’t want to think about her becauseI think about her, then it’s going to bring up the fact that I can’t bring her back, and it’s just going to make me sad,’ he said. “What’s the point in thinking about something sad  What’s the point of thinking about someone that you’ve lost and you’re never going to get back again  And I just decided not to talk about it.” Meghanaposs suicidal thoughts  In one of the most painful revelations, Harry delved further into his we’s mental state over the team she contemplated suicide. He said Meghan was only prevented from killing herself by concern over him “losing another woman in my le”. Barely a year into their marriage and while pregnant with their son Archie she began suffering deep depression. Expanding on the Duchess’s interview own interview with Winfrey in March, Harry opened up about his we’s struggle. “The thing that stopped her [Meghan] from seeing it through was how unfair it would be on me after everything that had happened to my mum and to now to be put in a position of losing another woman in my le - with a baby inside of her,our baby,” he said. “The scariest thing for her was her clarity of thought. She hadn’t ‘lost it.’ She wasn’t crazy. She wasn’t self-medicating, be it through pills or through alcohol. She was absolutely sober. “She was completely sane. Yet in the quiet of the night, these thoughts woke her up.” Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. Harry admitted he did not know how to handle her confession. “I’m somewhat ashamed of the way that I dealt with them,” he added. “And of course, because of the system that we were in and the responsibilities and the duties that we had, we had a quick cuddle and then we had to get changed to jump in a convoy with a police escort and drive to the Royal Albert Hall for a charity event. Then step out into a wall of cameras and pretend as though everything’s okay. “There wasn’t an option to say, ‘you know what, tonight, we’re not going to go’ because just imagine the stories that come from that.” Harry said the couple’s appearance at the event was a turning point for him, realising they could not continue the way they were. He said: “While my we and I were in those chairs, gripping each other’s hand, the moment the lights go down, Meghan starts crying. I’m feeling sorry for her, but I’m also really angry with myself that we’re stuck in this situation.” On Prince Phillipaposs funeral  The Duke said ing to London to attend his grandfather’s Prince Philip’s funeral last month meant he suffered again. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA university undergraduate was left partially blind after a faulty phone charger exploded and sparks flew into her eye. Law student Esther Modede, , from Birmingham, West Midlands, was plugging her phone in on the evening of April  when she noticed the wire looked a little damaged. Shortly after, Esther’s phone and the charger started burning up and she noticed smoke. Moments later the wire began exploding and one of the sparks hit Esther directly in the eye, leaving her unable to see out of her left eye. That night Esther spent four hours in hospital getting a bandage over her eye, which she had to keep on for three days. When the bandage was removed, Esther’s eyesight still wasn’t back to normal but she is slowly recovering.  Esther said: “I had borrowed my friends my charger over the weekend and when I got it back it was slightly damaged. “I didn’t think anything of it so I plugged in my phone to charge and it started burning up. “I didn’t think it was going to get any worse and then as I was recording it, it started sparking.  “I then got a spark in my eye and I couldn’t see very well at all. I didn’t realise I was that close or that the spark would be able to enter my eye. I was extremely worried. “Everything went blurry and when I closed my other eye I couldn’t see very well. “I had the bandage on my eye for three days. When I took the bandage off I couldn’t see very clearly, but my sight has cleared up and is still healing.” Esther was told by eye specialists at Birmingham City Hospital that the spark had damaged her cornea. She added: The surface of my eye was effected. The moment the spark hit my eye my eye shut and I felt it begin to swell. It was a hot sensation. The swelling and the blurring of my sight was worrying. My vision as of last week was still recovering but as of [now], currently, it’s a lot better and I can now read when the other eye is shut.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnEducationHospitalsStudents

story: NewsGeorge Floyd witness locked eyes with victim and just knew he was killing himEXCLUSIVE: One year on from the death of George Floyd, the first witness on the scene recalls the murder victim crying out for his mama as his le was being taken - and says he died because he was a black manmirrorShareByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCharles McMillian s to the death scene " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeWith his neck brutally pinned to the ground minutes from death, George Floyd locked eyes with Charles McMillian as he fought to speak his last few words. As others angrily focused on murderous police officer Derek Chauvin, the -year-old concentrated on the man whose le was ebbing away before him. “I just knew he was killing him,” said McMillian. “You could see it in George’s face. I could not help, as a black man in America and someone who has been arrested like he was, but think to myself that it could so easily have been me.” McMillian was speaking before the first anniversary of Floyd’s murder on Tuesday.His emotionally charged, powerful testimony paved the way for Chauvin’s murder conviction last month.  The father of eight wants to see the killer officer put away for le when he is sentenced on June . “He should get le,” he said. “They give us [black men] le, he should get le too. “I have no hard feelings towards Chauvin. I don’t want to give way to hate all I want to ask him is ‘Why ’” Fate brought McMillian and Chauvin together at the corner of th and Chicago Avenue in the tough southern district of Minneapolis on May  last year.  Five days earlier, the car wash worker had pulled level with the officer’s SUV at a red light. Looking across, he told Chauvin: “At the end of the day, go home to your family safe.” The policeman, , acknowledged his kindness before the light changed green, and the two went their separate ways. On the day of Floyd’s death, McMillian saw a police cruiser in his “hood” and stopped to see what was going on.  “Any other time, I might have just kept driving,” he explained. “We see this kind of thing every day in my hood. “I don’t know what made me stop this time. I was being nosy. Something told me something wasn’t right.” As he got out of his car, he became the first civilian on the scene of a crime that changed the world. He recalled: “The officer was trying to get him in the car and everything, talking to him.  I was telling him just to comply, get in the car because you can’t win. I’ve been where George was that day.” “I am not trying to win,” responded an increasingly distressed Floyd, who struggled with the police as they tried to get him into a police car. Repeatedly he told them he was “claustrophobic” and had anxiety. In now-famous videos, witnesses implore Chauvin to let Floyd, , breathe.  Yet McMillian, captured on police body cams wearing distinctive white framed glasses, a black T-shirt, beige shorts and white flip-flops, is the only one directly interacting with Floyd. “I kept my eyes focused only on George,” said McMillian, who can be heard pleading “Get up.” “I will. I can’t move,” Floyd responds. McMillian said: “It was then George began beginning for his mom. ‘Mama. Mama. Mama,’ he was crying out.  It really brought home how much he was struggling to live. I’d lost my mom a year before, and the pain was still raw in me. I understood him. “Chauvin didn’t care though. He seemed high on the power he had. “I said to him, ‘the man said he couldn’t breathe.’ They said, ‘ he keeps talking, well, he can breathe.’” After nine minutes and  seconds, Chauvin finally removed his weight as an ambulance arrived.  The attending paramedic said he was dead. After the body is removed, McMillian confronts Chauvin. Reminding him of their previous encounter, he tells him he “does not respect” what he just did and calls him a “maggot”. Today, McMillian says he hopes racism in America will be defeated but is fearful Floyd’s death will be in vain.  He said: “Being black in America is a disadvantaged way of le. George died for the colour of his skin, not from the crime they accused him of committing.” McMillian grew up picking cotton alongside his mother, Queen, on a farm in Mississippi. He moved from Aberdeen to Minnesota when he was . He bounced from one unskilled job to another and suffered from alcohol and drug addiction, but has been sober since . As we spoke with McMillian and his son, Charlie, , gunfire broke out  yards away between gang members. McMillian said: “Everything goes on in my hood. There is no dference today than before George was killed. It’s as dangerous now as it was then.” Though he is not hopeful for America, McMillian hopes people in the UK will continue to fight racial inequality. He said: “If anything good has come from George’s murder it’s that people are ready to be heard.” He has not been contacted by Floyd’s family or lawyers, but said: “It would be nice to meet them one day.
