In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I have been reading a lot of reports and letters in national and local newspapers about the problems experienced at the Rest and Be Thankful.I have no doubt that those charged with keeping the trunk road operational and safe for drivers are doing their best in the circumstances.However, there now seems to be an acceptance in Transport Scotland that a new solution has to be found.In a letter to the press, George Allan points out that the -mile route from Strathlachlan to Colintraive and the eight miles between Ormidale and Tighnabruaich were designed and constructed in  or  years.I was a member of the survey and design team on these routes. I was also involved in the construction of  miles of the A between Perth and Inverness in  years. These civil engineering schemes demonstrate what can be achieved when there is real political will and commitment to prioritise projects.I realise Transport Scotland has its own procedures for appointing consultants for the design processes and there are detailed environmental impact assessments to be done. It does, however, seem to me that its programming of the Rest and Be Thankful improvement is completely lacking in ambition.As a former director of roads and transport in Highland, perhaps I may be permitted to comment on the long-term solution.I would saythere are no geological features found on the other side of the glen which will cause a repeat of current problems, then the construction of a new road in ersion would cause less disruption to traffic than trying to form landslip shelters or tunnels adjacent to the existing carriageway.The main thing though is for Transport Scotland and their political masters to just get on with it.This week, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarks its eighth anniversary – after a year like no other.Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, our Helimed crews have never missed a beat maintaining our emergency helicopter air ambulance service across Scotland#s mainland and island communities. In fact we#ve enhanced our service with the launch of a new aircraft – Helimed  in Aberdeen last year – which has already had a huge impact on pre-hospital care in the Grampian, Highland and island regions.In our busiest year ever, our aircrew have endured challenging working conditions, with additional procedures and cumbersome protective and safety equipment as they go about an already dficult and stressful job.But they#re not complaining – this is what the Scottish public ask of them, to save and improve lives, wherever the need arises, and they fulfil their role with courage and pride.Our exemplary performance during this national crisis has been a tribute to how far SCAA has come in just eight years and I, for one, am immensely proud of what the SCAA team has achieved.But our operational teams are acutely aware that we are only able to provide this critical service, thanks to the continued public donations which you have maintained throughout these dficult times. So you are the real heroes in our charity.SCAA is the people#s helicopter – funded by the people of Scotland, for the people of Scotland – and our two frontline aircraft are stood by ready to help you, your family, your friends, colleagues, neighbours or anyone in your community when you most need us.As we mark our eighth birthday on May , we are asking the people of Scotland,they can, to support us into the future. Any donation, however small, to celebrate our anniversary will help to save a le – just like the numerous lives we have already saved over almost , missions.SCAA vows to continue to transform emergency care in Scotland, particularly to our rural and island communities, with your support. Thank you.As a coalition of leading providers of care and support to vulnerable children and young people, we congratulate all MSPs on their election and welcome the consensus there is between the major political parties to tackle the growing mental health crisis in our young people.We have for some time raised concerns over a potential lost generation of vulnerable children and young people, whose mental health is being impacted even further by the Covid- pandemic.There have been dramatically increased waiting times for mental health treatment during lockdown.In December , for example,  per cent of children and young people had been waiting more than a year for specialist treatment, compared with . per cent in , a truly frightening statistic.A commitment by MSPs to focus on mental health, increasing investment in support services and intervention strategies, must be a priority for this parliament, giving our young people the care and support they need, when they need it.The frightening statistics on the deteriorating mental health of many young people presents a compelling case for a radical new plan for our struggling mental health services and for a national crusade to address what is a mental health pandemic, underpinned by considerably greater resourcing.This is a crisis we can overcome, but it will require a similar energy and commitment to that demonstrated for Covid-we are to achieve this and prevent many young people giving up on their futures.At sight loss charity RNIB Scotland, we are concerned the Covid- crisis might have impacted on people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older.We would like to highlight the emotional reassurance and practical help we offer during the coronavirus lockdown and its aftermath.Covid has eclipsed all other health news in the past year but  people still start to lose their sight in Scotland every week. Add to that stress over Covid and the lockdowns and there could be more people needing support and reassurance.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute and the Western Highlands for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as families, friends and carers.Losing your sight can be devastating news to take in. But our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.The uncertainty during the Covid lockdown over access to basic shopping and medication, a lack of information in accessible formats, the social isolation, the barriers to being guided because of social distancing # these have all added to and compounded the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.But we want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.To contact the Need to Talk service, phone the RNIB Helpline on    or email needtotalk@rnib.org.uk

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.And yet…One night in the s, a young British student felt compelled to get up and pray for #Irina#. She had no idea who that was. A year later in London she met the Russian poet Irina Ratushinskaya, released from a labour camp in the USSR where she had been imprisoned for her Christian faith.Denied paper, she wrote poems on soap bars. In one poem she wrote:Believe me, it was often thus:I have never forgotten that extraordinary poem. How far can kindness reach In Mid Argyll there is a group of people who offer prayers for anyone who asks. You don#t have to be #religious# – whatever that means – to ask. You can ask for yourself or someone . It can be something huge, or something ordinary. It is totally confidential.People are sometimes touched that people they don#t know are thinking of them – a #sudden sense of joy and warmth, a resounding note of love#.Do ask. Contact us on midargyllprayers or on our Facebook page Mid Argyll Prayers.

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: get-paid-drink-beer-thanks-musselburgh-universitys-study
story: Itrsquos looking for  people to take part in a consumer taste trial where they will sample the beer.Run by the universityrsquos Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, the team is recruiting  people who are already stout drinkers ndash those who enjoy the occasional pint of Guinness, Belhaven Black or Murphyrsquos ndash as well as  who have not drunk stout before but are keen to try it.Recruitment for tasters starts now, with the trial to begin later this month.Each participant who completes tastings and provides the necessary feedback will be rewarded with a pound John Lewis or Amazon voucher as a thank you for taking part.Participants, ideally from Edinburgh and the Lothians, will be asked to pick up samples from the university and will be given two sample stout recipes to taste at home. They will need to complete an online questionnaire to provide feedback and highlight their preferred sample. Access to the internet is essential and the feedback process is believed to take about - minutes to complete.Catriona Liddle, who heads up the Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, is running the trial.She said: ldquoOur consumer tasting  are extremely popular with foodies and people from the local community who enjoy sampling and talking about food and drink. Itrsquos open to people who are already part of our existing consumer , but itrsquos also an opportunity for new people who might like to get involved in further food and drink tasting .ldquoWe normally have multiple sessions running on campus each week across all food types. The only consideration is that sadly we cannot accept any applications from those with food allergies or food restrictions.ldquoThe samples on this trial will be blind tested, so participants wonrsquot know which type of stout they are tasting, and we will be using the results to help create Scotlandrsquos favourite stout.Email the food team at consumer@qmu.ac.uk to apply.Participants must be aged  and over.

title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: historic-dunbar-methodist-church-saved-public-use
story: Dunbar Methodist Church ndash the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland ndash dates back to .However, in , the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged and began meeting at the latter.The Victoria Street building was later sold, with developer Monkscroft Properties Limited keen to ensure that ldquothe building remained in use as a public space and as an asset for the community of Dunbar.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department has given the go-ahead to change the building into a venue for weddings, s and community use.Ewan McIntyre, who is behind the scheme, was delighted to see progress being made.He said: ldquoThe best reason to buy the building was to make sure it did not get turned into housing. It is part of the fabric of Dunbar.Minimal changes are planned for the building, with replacement steps outside.The main church space has capacity for about  people for worship, with the developers looking to host ldquosmall and intimate weddings, with a reduced capacity of up to  people seated for lunch or dinner and up to  people in total for ceremonies and celebrations.Stained glass windows have been repaired, while other decoration has been completed inside the building.Members of the public will get the chance to look around the venue on May  and  at an open door event.However, the proposals did not win favour with everyone in the town.The planning department received three letters objecting to the plans, with concerns that there would be loud music played at the venue, disturbance with people congregating before, during and after events, and worries about where people attending events would park their cars.During the planning process, the applicants highlighted ldquorelationships with neighbours are crucial to the success of the venue and the utmost care will be given to managing guests and noise.Dunbarrsquos community council was among those who backed the proposals when they were first lodged with the local authority in summer last year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was pleased the scheme was progressing.She highlighted that the building was not listed and it could have been demolished or transformed to make way for housing.She was pleased the building would remain in community use.Mrs Swan said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled.ldquoI know that the Methodist church building, when it was a place of worship and dwindling congregation, was an uphill struggle to keep the building in good repair.ldquoIt is fantastic that it has got a new owner and wonderful it is being kept as a place of public assembly.

title: east-lothians-jamie-ramsay-cycling-across-uk-80-days-drum-support-olympics
story: Jamie Ramsay had planned to travel to the international showcase last year, cycling and sailing the whole way from London to Tokyo.But the coronavirus pandemic saw the event pushed back  months, with Jamie, from Whittingehame, now going on a journey with a dference.It will see him complete  days of socially distanced cycling around the UK through June and July.The -year-old, sponsored by Whole Earth , said: ldquoIrsquom disappointed not to be able to go the whole way to Japan but am really looking forward to meeting fellow Team GB supporters in Scotland and around Britain.ldquoWersquore all in this pandemic together and need a bit of fun. I hope my passion and determination to do this challenge will get people in Scotland behind our Team GB heroes and show the benefits of exercise and nutrition on positive mental attitude and wellbeing.The journey will take Jamie ndash who has previously cycled from Sao Paulo in Brazil to Boliviarsquos La Paz, and run from Vancouver in Canada to Argentinarsquos capital city Buenos Aires ndash around Britain.The former Belhaven Hill, Stenton Primary and Loretto School pupil will pass through towns and cities twinned with or named after places along his original route, including Moscow in East Ayrshire and Holland in Hampshire.Instead of ending up in Tokyo, he will be crossing the finishing line in lsquoStokeyorsquo, also known as Stoke-on-Trent.Visiting Team GB athletesrsquo families, schools and fans en route, Jamie will record their cheers and waves on doorsteps, creating the biggest virtual Mexican wave to spur on Team GB hopefuls.His gruelling challenge will also see him climb Ben Nevis, cycle Hadrianrsquos Wall, and swim the Blue Lagoon in Abereiddy in south-west Wales.Last Tuesday, two-time Olympic rowing champion Helen Glover fired the starting gun from Londonrsquos  Queen Elizabeth Park to signal the start of Jamiersquos journey.Helen, who is aiming for a hat-trick of Olympic gold medals when the Games get under way in July, said: ldquoOur fans mean everything to us but wersquore now facing a Games this summer with no British spectators in Tokyo.ldquoJamiersquos epic journey to help get fans behind us is awe-inspiring. We have so much respect for his perseverance and hope hersquoll spur us on to bring gold home for our fans this summer.Follow Jamiersquos progress at wholeearthfoods teamgb wholewayjourney

title: north-berwicks-catriona-matthew-unveils-solheim-cup-sculpture-gleneagles
story: Europe edged out the United States frac - frac to win the competition at Gleneagles for the first time since .Now, a commemorative sculpture, created by Scottish artist Jephson Robb, has been unveiled in front of the captain and key representatives from Gleneagles, Event Scotland and PING Europe.Catriona, who won the Solheim Cup three times as a player, unveiled lsquoMatchrsquo last month.She said: ldquoTeam Europersquos victory on Scottish soil will always remain one of the greatest achievements of my career.ldquoIrsquom sure this wonderful sculpture will also remind the many thousands who visit Gleneagles each year of a truly exceptional Solheim Cup I will certainly never forget.Catriona, of North Berwick, is due to lead Team Europe again later this year as they look to retain the trophy at the Inverness Club in Ohio, with the tournament teeing off on August .Jephson ndash one of only a few Scottish artists to have work in the permanent collection of the prestigious Museum of Modern Art, New York ndash was commissioned to create a permanent sculpture as a lasting reminder of the event.More than , spectators visited the -acre Perthshire estate, a record attendance for a womenrsquos UK golf tournament.At . metres tall, referencing the average height of the competitors, the stainless-steel mirror polished sculpture sits atop a Scottish Whinstone circular plinth which is inscribed with the names of players, captains and assistants, and the final score.

title: modern-day-makeover-historic-ormiston-footpath
story: The path, known locally as Clarty Loan, links Park Road and Limeylands Road.It was once used by coal miners on their way to and from work at the four mines surrounding the village.It is now used by local residents as a shortcut to the local shops, park and primary school, and is also seen as a safe route since it is not suitable for vehicles.With new homes being built in and around Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association suggested that upgrading the path would be of great benefit to the local community and area.Walker Homes, which is building properties in the west of the village, agreed to fund the reinstatement of the path and pay East Lothian Council to do so.The improvement works consist of new lighting along the walkway.The issue of lighting along Clarty Loan was raised with the local housing partnership at East Lothian Council, which agreed to fund light installation.Mark Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association chairman, said: ldquoNow all the agreed work has been done and the path is looking fantastic.Peter Matthews, Walker Group managing director, said: ldquoWersquove worked hard to deliver a well-designed place to be enjoyed by families who live in the Long Meadow development and the wider village.ldquoAs part of our agreement with the council, we provided funds to ensure the path which runs along the side of the development was upgraded.ldquoAs a responsible developer, as well as delivering high-quality developments for our customers, wersquore committed to providing opportunities to enhance the local area and contribute investment to benefit surrounding communities.

title: traditional-tents-replaced-wooden-cabins-holiday-campsite
story: Scripture Union Scotland has been running camping holidays at Scoughall Farm, east of North Berwick, since the early s.Now, changes to the campsite will see five wooden cabins, as well as a pod, put in place of the tents.The charity, which uses the site from March through to October, runs ldquomulti-activity, resident events for young people.It said: ldquoThis change will enable us to meet the changing expectations of young people without departing from the historical style of the campsite.ldquoThe new buildings will be located in the same area as the tents were pitched and will allow the site to be used to its full potential throughout the season.ldquoThere is no plan to increase the capacity of the site or theof the season.ldquoThe buildings will be supplied with electricity by linking to the on-site supply or from small inidual solar units attached to each building ndash there will be no other utilities supplied.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the proposals last week, with no members of the public objecting to the scheme.The local authority imposed two conditions: that the accommodation can be used only from March to October, and only by Scripture Union Scotland or an organisation on its behalf.

title: former-animal-mart-east-linton-given-go-ahead-host-parties-events
story: The owners of The Mart, East Linton, were initially given temporary permission to use the restored building for events in  but the Covid- outbreak saw the approval lapse.Now, they have applied for the right to hold a range of celebrations in the building, which they acknowledge was not built to ldquocontain high levels of sound.And East Lothian Council has given them the go-ahead to host events until the end of this year, while restricting how often they can have amplied music or sound.The Mart owners applied for the building, which sits in the centre of a restored site with a farm shop, cafe and market stalls, to be given Class  status.That would allow it to host events such as birthday parties, weddings, christenings and baby showers.There are also plans to hold community events such as gala day at the building and hold film nights.But issuing its approval of the change in use, council planners insisted it could not have nightly noisy events.They added as one of its conditions that ldquono events involving amplied music and or amplied speech shall fall on consecutivedays.A former animal auction mart, the hexagonal timber building was built in about  and is Category B listed.Applying for the change of use on behalf of The Mart, Urban Animation said: ldquoThe Mart business has invested heavily in bringing the building back into active use, after years ofdecay and listing on the Buildings at Risk Register.ldquoIt is a Listed Building which has been restoredto the highest standard and is once again a valued asset to the Mart site and East Lothian.ldquoIt isnow essential that the building is able to operate as a flexible space, accommodating a moreerse and productive range of new uses and activities.

title: order-free-lateral-flow-covid-test-scotland
story: People can order test packages online for home delivery by following details on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, the nose and throat swab tests can be collected from covid testing centres in the afternoons or early evening.Heres what you need to know:A negative lateral flow test that I took today.You can order free packs of rapid lateral flow tests to be sent to your homeyou live in Scotland, are over  and:There are dferent tests you can get to checkyou have coronavirus . The test you need depends on why youre getting tested.The twomain tests are:Both tests are free.A rapid lateral flow testpack contains seventests.You can only order one pack per household each day.You can order a test here.If you have someone on the shielding list in your household or are planning to travel to a Scottish island, select yes when the site asksyou were asked to get tested by a local authority or by an NHS Public Health team.For those travelling to a Scottish island, they should also click Scotland under the where in the UK do you live question, eventhey live in England, Wales or Northern Ireland.Results will be displayed on the handheld device which comes with the test - heres what they mean:You must self-isolate immediately to prevent any further transmission.What a positive test looks like.Chief Medical Officer Dr Gregor Smith explained: "This expansion builds on our existing testing strategy, and will help our efforts to ease the country out of lockdown safely."Routine testing is already available for people with no symptoms in a wide range of settings, including schools, high-risk workplaces, and communities where Covid- rates remain stubbornly high."Rapid lateral flow testing is already helping us to find cases that might otherwise have been missed, as around one in three people with Covid- do not show symptoms."Thats why its vital people can access testing, eventhey dont feel unwell. It will help protect the people around you, and help us avoid anotherto lockdown."It may be tempting to think as vaccinations increase and cases drop, that testing will become less important."In fact, this will only make it more important to spot and prevent new outbreaks as cases emerge."We know from our experience of last summer just how quickly one outbreak can lead to another."This also applies regardless of whether you have been vaccinated or not."While the latest evidence suggests vaccines provide a high level of protection against the effects of Covid-, they dont yet provide a guarantee that you cant still get the virus or pass it on to others."Follow these stepsyoursquore doing a rapid LFD test at home.Ifyou do not have coronavirus symptoms but live in a community that has been targeted for testing, you can access a test at a rapid test site.These are only available in some parts of Scotland.You can usually just turn up and do not need to book in advance ndash but you should check the arrangements at your local site first.You will be tested using a lateral flow devicewhich involves taking a swab or saliva sample.You should usually get your result within an hour.The First Minister also added that people visiting the islands should take two lateral flow tests before travelling.Nicola Sturgeon said: "We are keeping island communities at the same level as the rest of the country at the moment, so that we can allow travel between island communities and the rest of Scotland."But we know this does create a risk for our island communities."Many of them currently have very, very low rates of Covid."And they will be welcoming visitors from parts of Scotland which I know many of them are looking forward to where Covid will still be circulating at a higher level and more widely."So If you are planning to travel to an island we do encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you are planning to travel, and the first should be three days before you travel."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test - which is more sensitive - to confirm the result before making a final decision on cancelling your visit."This is potentially an important way in which we can minimise the risk, of bringing Covid into island communities while nevertheless allowing our island communities the benefit of opening up again to visitors."Soyou are planning on travelling to an island over the course of next week, it is possible to get tests from today, and I would encourage you to do that."

title: covid-vaccine-passport-scheme-announced-scotland
story: Those who have been vaccinated can download a letter from the NHS Inform patient website, or request a letter from the Covid Status Helplinethey are not online.But as details of the vaccination status scheme were announced, Scotlandrsquos Chief Medical Officer Dr Gregor Smith urged people to be "highly cautious about international travel"and ldquocontinue to limit their travel abroad.Only those travelling to a country where proof of vaccination is needed as an entry requirement should request a letter.There are currently no countries that require travellers to show their vaccination status, but the letter scheme is being introduced because international travel requirements can change quickly during the pandemic.If yoursquore planning to travel abroad, you must:Countries may move between the green, amber and red lists at short notice.You should not assume that a country on the green, amber or red list now will remain on the same list over the weeks and months ahead.Before you travelYoull also need to:While in Scotland, you must at all times follow therules on Covid-.Testing while isolating in your hotelWhile staying in your hotel, youll need to take a Covid- test on day twoand day eightof your  day stay. These tests will be delivered to you at your hotel.If either of these tests are positive for COVID-, you may need to quarantine at your hotel for longer than  days.The cost of isolating in a hotelTo isolate in a hotel, youll need to pay:Theres no charge for children under .If you need to stay longer than  days because youa positive Covid- test, or because you have been told you are a close contact of someone who has tested positive, you must book extra days through theCTM booking portal.There will be no charge for these extra days.If you have been in a country or area on the red list at any point in the  days before arriving in Scotland, you will only be allowed to enter theUK either:You should not travel to red list countries or areas on holiday, or for any leisure purposes.Before travelling to Scotland from a red list country, yoursquoll need to:On arrival in Scotland,you mustquarantine in the hotel yoursquove booked for  days. If you test positive for Covid- while in quarantine, you may need to quarantine for longer.If yoursquove been in an amber list country in the  days before travelling to Scotland, you must:On arrival in Scotland you must:Before travelling to Scotland from a green list country or area, you must:You will not need to isolate unless:the result of the Covid- test yoursquove taken on day twoafter arriving back in Scotland is positiveThe Scottish Government said it hopes allowing people to download their own documents will ease the burden on the NHS, as travellers will not need to ask their GP for a letter.As the vaccination programme progresses, digital Covid Status Certicates, which will include vaccination and testing data, will be brought in for international travel.Dr Smith said: "Given the risk of ing with infection, and especially of introducing new iants of the virus, we continue to be highly cautious about international travel."Everyone should continue to limit their travel abroad and while I understand the need for some people who want to reunite with family, when it comes to holidays my advice continues to be play it safe and staycation this summer."For those that do need it, this new service will provide people with a record of their vaccination status for outbound international travel."They should only access their recordthey are planning to travel within  days and it is a requirement of their destination."

title: weekly-collections-coming-part-major-changes-recycling-east-lothian
story: Currently, households in East Lothian have green and blue recycling boxes which are collected once a fortnight, with plastic, glass and cans sorted into the green box and paper, card and cardboard into the blue box.However, from August, residents will see their collections increase in frequency to once every week, but will be tasked with sorting their recycling into four piles rather than two.The four separate streams are: plastics, cans and cartons glass bottles and jars paper and card and cardboard.Paper and card will continue to be collected in the existing blue boxes, with cardboard to either be sorted into a separate blue box or flattened and presented beside the boxes or in another cardboard box.Glass bottles and jars will continue to be collected in the existing green box, although these will be replaced with new black boxes in the future.Plastics, cans and cartons will be collected in a new container, which East Lothian Council describes as a ldquosealable, weighted, reusable bag.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe bag capacity is larger than the existing green boxes, can be self-sealed ndash so no need to attach a cover ndash and the bags are weighted to help prevent these lighter materials blowing away.The change will also coincide with the rollout of new collection vehicles which will pick up recycling and food waste at the same time.The council spokeswoman explained the reasons behind the changes.She said: ldquoIn , East Lothian Council became signatories to the Scottish Governmentrsquos Household Waste Charter, which aims to have all councils in Scotland collecting glass separate from plastic and cans, and cardboard and paper separate to the other materials.ldquoAs part of our commitment to both the charter and to tackling the climate emergency, we are changing our recycling services to a charter-aligned collection model that delivers best value through theof high-quality resources to the commodities market, while at the same time reducing the carbon impact of our waste and recycling services.ldquoFrom August, the collections will be carried out using specially designed resource recovery vehicles that can collect all the dferent materials and the food waste at the same time every week, reducing the number of times we have to visit each street by a third every year.She added that the move to weekly collections ldquoshould mean that many residents will store and present fewer containers than they currently do with the fortnightly service.The planned changes have been revealed after a multi-million-pound contract was signed to see a new company collect East Lothianrsquos recycling and food waste.FCC Environmentrsquos contract with East Lothian Council began on May  and will run until March .A new contract to collect East Lothianrsquos recycling and food waste has been signed. From left: Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Councilrsquos environment spokesperson Steve Longdon, operations director, FCC Environment Mark Barnfield, head of municipal collections and streetscene Tom Reid, head of infrastructure at East Lothian Council and Bob Martin, contract manager, FCC EnvironmentThe contract, worth up to pound. million, was previously held by Bfa.Under the contract, FCC Environment will collect recycling and food waste from ,#properties.Tom Reid, head of infrastructure for East Lothian Council, said: ldquoBig improvements are coming to our recycling services over the next few years as our population grows.

title: pub-owners-managers-east-lothian-delighted-welcome-back-customers-week
story: On Monday, most of mainland Scotland entered Level  restrictions.This meant for hospitality venues the ability to serve alcohol inside, with two-hour slots to be booked and venues to close at .pm.Craig Douglas, owner of The Victoria Inn in Haddington, said that while it was ldquogood to get a sense of normality back, he was still a bit concerned for the future.The pub on Court Street, which opened under its current owner in October , has been closed more than it has been open because of the pandemic.It had reopened on April  but closed a week later due to the weather, reopening once more on Monday.Craig said: ldquoI relish the thought of being open again and able to serve my customers. We have refurbished to give people a lot more room and have launched a new menu and cheaper drinks. But I am not holding out much hope.ldquoIrsquove lost pound, in both food and drink stock from the first and second lockdown. People have been used to buying alcohol from supermarkets and drinking that in their own homes: they can buy a bottle of wine for less than pound but a bottle in a pub is about pound-pound.ldquoI just hope people are going to come back and show faith in pubs.Concern was echoed by bosses at Hole in the Wa pub in Musselburgh.A spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is not too bad but it is dficult to follow social distancing in the sense of keeping people apart itrsquos took our capacity right down but wersquove just got to do it.ldquoIt is great to be back and great to see the regulars but sad that we canrsquot have the full capacity.Wullie Gordon, manager at the Brig Inn in Tranent, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted to be able to serve alcohol inside again.ldquoFor the people that come into pubs rather than just the beer gardens, they are getting the chance to socialise and meet their friends againldquoIrsquom just happy to have customers there arenrsquot very many pubs in Tranent anymore.

title: two-different-sections-a1-east-lothian-overnight-closures-coming-days
story: First, roadworks on the A between the Thistly Cross and Abbotsview junctions mean the road will be closed between Dunbar and Haddington from pm on Saturday until am the following day.A spokesman for Bear Scotland confirmed that work was being carried out by Keltbray on behalf of ScottishPower.He said that Keltbray had produced a statement, which reads: ldquoKeltbray, on behalf of ScottishPower, are carrying out essential work on a section of overhead lines between Saturday at pm and Sunday at am which will result in the closure of a section of the A.ldquoThis will include work on the high voltage and low voltage networks, changing electricity poles and overhead power cables.ldquoWe are replacing and refurbishing equipment which is coming to the end of its serviceable le, which is essential works to make sure we maintain a good quality of supply for our customers.ldquoA ersion route will be in place.A second closure then takes place on the westboundcarriage of the A between the Wallyford and Old Craighall junctions for resurfacing works on Monday and Tuesday nights.The section of road will be closed from .pm until am both nights.The works will see Transport Scotlandrsquos operating company BEAR Scotland resurface a -metre section of carriageway.A ersion will be in place taking motorists through the A, A and onto the Edinburgh City Bypass . It adds an estimated seven minutes or two miles to journeys.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese surfacing improvements will signicantly improve ride quality and safety for motorists using the A at this location.ldquoIt is essential for safety that we close the northbound carriageway during these works, however wersquove scheduled them overnight in order to minimise the impact.ldquoWe thank motorists and the local community in advance for their patience and understanding.

title: east-lothian-council-extension-big
story: The proposed extension to a cottage atGarleton, near Haddington, was rejected because East Lothian planners ruled it was bigger than the original building.However, their claim it was the same as building another house in the countryside, which goes against council policy, has been thrown out by councillors on appeal.A virtual meeting of the councilrsquos Local Review Body saw an appeal by the homeowners upheld after members said they were ldquocomfortable with the extension.The original plans to extend Nouster Cottage were, agents for the owners said, to allow an inter-generational family to live together at the property.The single-storey cottage, which had already had extensions added over the years, would have a new one and a half-storey extension including a boot room, hallway, playroom, snooker room and three bedrooms, and would add eight new rooms and two bathrooms to the three-bedroom cottage.But while planners described the extension as bigger than the house, agents APT Planning said that once outbuildings and a conservatory due to be demolished as part of the work were taken into account, it only made up a third of the cottagersquos footprint.They told the review body: ldquoWe strongly refute the conclusion that this is effectively a new house in the countryside, it very clearly is not.No objections to the plans were lodged but there were letters of support for the family.The agents said that the family bought the cottageto accommodate their growing multi-generational family.They added: ldquoThe family has two young boys and also an ageing parent with a degenerative disease.ldquoTheaccommodation has been designed with the three generations of family in mind, blending the needs of young and old and so that the grandparent can live comfortably on the ground floor .The review body agreed to uphold the appeal against the decision to refuse permission for the extension.Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoIt is an existingproperty being extended and I am comfortable approving it.Fellow review body member Jeremy Findlay agreed, along with convenorCouncillor John McMillan.A condition to replace or retain some trees which might be affected by the build was included and councillors also asked that a garage planned as part of the extension should have a condition stopping it from being used as additional accommodation.Councillor Findlay added: ldquoWe have had incidents in Gullane where people have built garages then surreptitiously added a room or two, so I feel strongly about this condition.

title: east-lothian-food-drink-businesses-vote-whether-continue-business-improvement-district
story: First created in , East Lothian Food  Drink Business Improvement District, in partnership with East Lothian Council and Queen Margaret University, has worked to promote East Lothian food and drink businesses.By creating a unying voice and marketing East Lothian as a quality provider of outstanding produce, the sector has benefited from a range of initiatives from direct selling to attendance at events and the creation of a digital marketing .Now, eligible businesses have the opportunity to vote on a second term and to continue to work together and drive the rebuilding of the food and drink sector in East Lothian following the impacts of recent lockdowns, stay-at-home orders and physical distancing.BIDs in Scotland have traditionally been focused on urban high streets, encompassing a number of dferent businesses. The East Lothian Food  Drink BID pioneered a new type of BID involving a single sector with a wider geographical area it remains the only food and drink sector BID in Scotland.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Provost, said: ldquoThe initial five years has seen many highlights and Scotlandrsquos Food  Drink County is fast becoming a highly visible brand.ldquoFrom member feedback, we know that working in this collaborative way is bringing real benefits.ldquoI would urge all eligible local businesses to vote to continue this fantastic collaboration for another five years.East Lothian Council has committed to continued financial support of the BIDthe vote to continue for a further five years is successful.It will also continue to provide expertise through membership of the board and the support of the economic development team.Chris Luca, chair of East Lothian Food  Drink, said: ldquoAs a local food and drink producer, the East Lothian Food  Drink BID has provided us with a great opportunity to work together and make the changes we as a sector want.

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-cases-rise-scotland
story: The First Minister has confirmed that Moray will move to Level  from midnight tonight, Glasgow City will remain in Level  for at least a further week and East Renfrewshire will stay in Level  - despite high cases in the area.Travel restrictions have also been brought in for some parts of England.Heres what you need to know:The First Minister confirmed that Glasgow will stay in Level  lockdown.Ms Sturgeon said: "Over the past  days, there have been extensive public health measures deployed across the city - including enhanced testing and vaccination in the areas with the highest rates of Covid, especially in G and G.She added: "Last week, we were seeing  cases for every , of the population - thats now risen to ."That increase will partly be due to the fact theres more testing being done, but the percentage of positive tests has also increased from .% to %."In summary, we dont think that we have turned the corner in Glasgow yet."Let me stress that were confident the major public health interventions underway will be effective, and they will bring the virus rates back under control - but they need a bit longer to do that."We also need a bit more time to be confident than we are now that vaccination will stop the rising case numbers today becoming severe illness and sharply rising hospital numbers a couple of weeks from now."So for all these reasons, I can confirm today that regrettably, Glasgow will remain in Level  for another week at this stage."I know, not least because I live in Glasgow myself, how unwelcome this is for iniduals and businesses - but I hope it wont be for much longer."Nicola Sturgeon announced that East Renfrewshire will stay in Level  despite high case numbers.The First Minister said: "On the face of it, levels in East Renfrewshire - as a proportion of the population - are actually slightly higher than in Glasgow."Im acutely aware that people might therefore look at the raw data and sayGlasgow is in Level , East Renfrewshire should be there too."But as youve heard me say many times before, and I know this is really dficult, the situation underneath the raw data is often more complex and its the detailed analysis that we must try to base our decisions on."For example, while the cases per , in Glasgow and East Renfrewshire are similar, the total number of cases in East Renfrewshire - because its a smaller area, obviously - is signicantly smaller than in Glasgow."To illustrate that, yesterday there were actually just  new cases reported in East Renfrewshire - compared to  in Glasgow. More importantly, many more of the cases in East Renfrewshire can be traced to specic household clusters, unlike in Glasgow."That means that we think strong and targeted public health measures have more of a chance of stemming the rise in East Renfrewshire, without the need to use wider restrictions."Taking all of that into account, our judgement - and these decisions are often finely balanced - is that East Renfrewshire should stay at Level  for now, although this will be kept under close review and well continue to use enhanced public health measures."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will move to Level  from midnight tonight.Ms Sturgeon said: "Im very pleased to say that the situation has actually improved very signicantly."Last week, the area was reporting  new cases a week per , - thats now fallen to ."Positivity rate in Moray has also fallen quite markedly, from .% a week ago to .% now."In addition, the April- iant does not seem to be as commonly present in Moray as it is in Glasgow and indeed other parts of the country."Im able to confirm today that Moray will now move down from Level  to Level , taking effect on midnight tonight."This, I know, will be welcome news for people and businesses in Moray - and its been made possible by efforts of local public health teams and the public."I would say though that its important to remain careful."Being in Level  still comes with necessary restrictions, so please stick to those and do everything you can to help Moray to enjoy more freedoms and more easing of restrictions later this summer."The First Minister announced travel restrictions between Scotland and three areas in England.NS: "However, there are particularly serious outbreaks of the April- iant in three specic areas of England: Bedford, Bolton and Blackburn  Darwen."For that reason, from Monday, we are imposing temporary travel restrictions on travel between Scotland and those  areas."Soyou were planning to visit friends or relatives, or to say in those areas - Bedford, Bolton or Blackburn  Darwen - you must delay your visit."The First Minister said that the iant may be more transmissible than the Kent iant.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent weeks, this iant has become quite established in many parts of the UK, including in Scotland, and we have reason to believe it might be even more transmissible than the Kent iant."The First Minister said that the latest estimate we have of the R suggests it might be slightly above oneagain.This means that the virus numbers are still growing across Scotland.There have been  new cases of Covid- reported inScotland in the past  hours -.%of tests.According to Scottish Government statistics, there havebeen nonewdeaths in the same period.Fourpeople are in intensive care, with  in hospital with recently confirmed Covid-.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus.The total number of positive cases reported yesterday was .  of these were in Greater Glasgow  Clyde,  in Lanarkshire and  in Lothian.,,people have received the first dose of the Covid vaccination and,,have received their second dose.

title: pro-union-parties-indyref2-obsession-fuelling-debate
story: In part, this obsession has led to the SNP being let off the hook for its failures in government as was reflected in this weekendrsquos election results and perpetuated by every media outlet across the country zoning in on constitutional questions.Over the past few weeks, the majority of pro-Union politicians have used every sound clip offered to them to exclaim their anti-independence thoughts rather than explain how they propose to get this country back on its feet and how they could work with the Government to put recovery first.With all eyes focused on the constitution, it has worked in the favour of the SNP who have managed to be elected to Government with a record number of votes, despite their failings over the past  years in charge.The First Minister herself admitted during the campaign that she had taken her ldquoeye off the ball as Scotland racked up the highest drugs death in Europe. But there doesnrsquot appear to have been any rebuke for the drugs deaths crisis, their failed education record, missed hospital waiting time targets, rising child poverty rates, the exam results scandal, or failures in local policing.The next Scottish Government has an opportunity over the next five years to make amends for past failures and getting caught up in an independence campaign will only take the SNPrsquos eye off the ball once again.However, the SNP did not win a majority in the election and as a minority government will require support from other parties to pass budgets and any major reforms.The Scottish Greens will likely prop up the SNP in future policy discussions, but this will requirepolicy trade-offs infor budget support.With COP firmly in the sights of both parties as an opportunity to showcase Scotland as a leader in tackling climate change on the global stage, will the Scottish Greens be willing to lend support to independence which could risk the SNP taking its focus off meeting its emissions reduction targets of % by  ndash which it has done for the past two years in a row.They have already said they want bold action from the Scottish Government and now they are in a position to bargain for this.Read more:Indyref and a blinkered green agenda could harm Scottish farmings futureDuring Sundayrsquos Andrew Marr programme, a suggestion of next spring to hold another referendum was put to the First Minister, to which, of course, she said she was contemplating. Nicola Sturgeon hasnrsquot officially committed to a timescale, other than the first half of the next parliamentary term, but it would appear that the media is setting the ball rolling by proposing such a timeline. As much as I have criticised the SNP for pedalling talks of Indyref during a pandemic, journalists are also guilty of fuelling the debate and diminishing print space or airtime for more immediate and pressing issues.Over the past week I have been moving into my new house, which has involved many hours of deep cleaning whilst tuned in to my radio and coverage of the election.Hats off to BBC Radio Scotland team for managing to fill three daysrsquo worth of election coverage with very little to report on other than the one major news story: would the SNP gain a majority Although they covered results and reaction across the entire country, the main topic on every reportersrsquo lips was whether the SNP would have a mandate to hold another referendum. So, for every listener tuned in, we are being told that this is the discussion we need to be having, this is the headline we should all be taking away.In between googling tutorials on how to sand kitchen worktops, I checked in to the community Facebook page for my local village and was struck by the fact that none of the members were remotely engaged in discussions over the election, let alone independence. Like many other communities across the country, this village is still in the grips of a pandemic, so quite understandably, most posts and discussions revolved around Covid advice and best practice, information about the local youth club reopening, as well as a series of church services.Read more:Scottish election: Indyref cant continue to dominate the next five years mdash there are bigger issuesMembers were posting aboutfitness camps and slots which had come available for hairdressers and beauty salons. Local businesses desperate to rebuild and get customers in their doors.Economic recovery is what matters to so many, yet we are so embroiled in constitutional questions that we lose sight of the ramications the past year has had for so many businesses and iniduals who have lost their jobs and families living below thepoverty line.There is no denying the fact that there is indeed an appetite to reopen the debate around independence, the recent vote shows an almost   split down the middle, but I do not believe it should be up to the media to frame the discussion.There is a huge job ahead for the next Scottish Government to deliver on a national recovery and all opposition politicians and members of the press must be focused on holding them accountable for the measures they are taking to get the country back on its feet.Letrsquos not do Alex Salmondrsquos job for him by inadvertently holding the SNPrsquos feet to the fire over independence but instead hold their feet to the fire over the nationrsquos recovery from the pandemic.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: gardening-houseplants-can-make-feel-like-abroad
story: If youre planning a staycation this summer, there are ways to enjoy a taste of the tropics without any thoughts of getting on a plane.So say houseplant enthusiasts and social media influencers Igor Josovic-Kemper and Judith de Graaff of Urban Jungle Bloggers , offering inspiration and ideas to their .m Instagram followers.In partnership with The Joy Of Plants , an initiative from the Flower Council of Holland, they have come up with ideas as to how you can be transported to the Mediterranean, Morocco and even Japan by filling your home with plants commonly found in foreign climes.Here Josovic-Kemper and de Graaff answer all our questions about how to use houseplants to conjure up a holiday, and help your specimens thrive.How big a space do you need You really can transform any space, no matter how big or small, as long as theres room to sit, relax and embrace feeling good. It could be your living room or home office, or simply a bright corner of your kitchen or a balconyyou live in a flat. Just wherever you feel good and where you can relax like you would on holiday, surrounded by plants.Are there rules for where you place your plants Plants love light and require it for photosynthesis. However, the amount of light they need to thrive is particular to each plant. For example, cacti and succulents generally love the bright sun on the windowsill.Which plants are likely to give you least trouble Calathea zebrina, aloe, sansevieria, spider plants, pothos and peace lily.How do you match your plants to your decor Find your plants some beautul pots and baskets. Perhaps you could go for a handwoven basket that matches the colour palette and style of your interior. This may be custom-designed, a classic terracotta pot, a vintage planter, or you can even make your own ceramic pots at a workshop.Which houseplants are trickier to grow Usually, plants that grow in very dferent native conditions such as high humidity can pose some challenges when growing them indoors. This includes alocasia, the banana palm and some philodendrons. Others such as the date palm require specic temperatures and lots of space to grow, which can also present challenges indoors.Which houseplants prefer shadier conditions For shadier conditions we recommend the ZZ plant , epipremnum, the Philodendron Brasil, as well as colocasia and azalea.Which houseplants can be moved to a sunny patio or balcony and can be left out in summer As long as temperatures dont drop too muchduring the warmer months, plants like the banana palm, kentia palm, agaves, opuntia, kalanchoe, crassula, haworthia and chamaerops palm can be kept outside at night.Some, like the palms and certain succulents, can even be kept outdoors all year long, but need to be protected from frost. Also ensure the soil and pot are well drained to prevent root rot due to heavy rainfall.How can the plants be cared for when the weather cools Before bringing your plants inside, check them for pests that they picked up outside. Make sure you find them a spot in your home where they get a similar amount of daylight as on your balcony or patio.Expect some leaf drop from the adjustment to new light conditions, which is normal, and help your plant by removing the dead leaves.Avoid any extreme changes in temperature and dont put your plants near or on top of the radiator, or next to a front door that opens frequently, as sudden hot and cold draughts can cause the plants stress.When you bring your plants inside, or when you start heating your home again during the colder months, adjust your watering schedule. Most plants require less water during hibernation, butyour apartment is very dry, use a humidier to keep your plants happy.Also, foliage growth slows down considerably during autumn and winter so you can stop fertilising until spring.Which houseplants will match your chosen destination Moroccan riad: Banana palm, papyrus plant, colocasia, Phoenix canariensis , bougainvillea, oleander, agave.Mediterranean haven: Lavender, Opuntia cacti, eucalyptus, olive tree, any kind of citrus tree, Chamaerops palm.Australian rainforest: Kentia palm, Schefflera actinophyla, umbrella tree, Epipremnum pinnatum, Alocasia brisbanensis, Hoya australis, Staghorn fern.South African safari: Strelitzia nicolai, kalanchoe, Zamioculcas zamiolia, string of pearls, crassula, Euphorbia ingens, haworthia, protea.Japanese garden: Azalea, Japanese spindle, moss balls , bonsai trees, a mini zen garden, Japanese painted fern.Amazonian jungle: Philodendrons of all sorts including monsteras, Thaumatophyllum xanadu, Calathea Burle Marxii, Calathea ornata, Begonia maculata, orchids, airplants, heliconia, dieffenbachia.

title: letters-government-allowed-human-nature-let-fans-ibrox
story: In the circumstances it is not surprising that their dedicated fans wanted to celebrate boisterously.However, like many, I was totally appalled at the scenes of Rangers fans all crowding together and behaving so badly. Well, I was appalled until I read that Rangers FC, understanding their fans very well, had tried to pre-empt trouble and ensure a celebration that would be both safe and satisfy their fans enthusiasm.They knew that it would not be possible to stop fans from inidually and separately deciding to go to Ibrox to celebrate this remarkable victory, so how much better to manage the process.In April, the chairman of the club wrote to the Scottish Government suggesting that, on four successive nights, , season ticket holders could be invited to Ibrox to join an in-stadium celebration.The request was turned down on the grounds that it did not comply with Covid rules. In my book this makes the Scottish Government culpable for the scenes in Glasgow, yet I see that the same Scottish Government is now heaping all the blame on to the football club and trying to work out how to punish it.Itrsquos no good Nicola Sturgeon emoting about how she feels our painshe does not understand human nature. The Rangers fans were always going to gather to celebrate in the same way that those grieving over Sarah Everadersquos disappearance were always going to gather in a vigil. How much better in both instancethe governments concerned had recognised the force of human emotion and allowed both events to take place safely, as proposed. Therersquos no virtue in being all bossy and sticking to the rulesit leads to a situation that canrsquot then be controlled. In any case, the Covid rules are not absolutes ndash they y too much between the four nations for that to be true.Judith Gillespie, Edinburgh.DONT BLAME SNP FOR VIOLENCESURELY only someone as blinkered as Brian Wilsonwould attempt to blame the SNP for the violent attacks on the police by unionist mobs in George Square. It is noticeable that the carnage has not been condemned by Tory politicians or by Scotland in Union officials.Mr Wilson also ignores the clear scientic advice that shows poor ventilation in crowded indoor situations combined with the effects of alcohol makes the spreading of Covid much more likely.There is no reason for Scotland to follow Boris Johnsonrsquos disastrous handling of Covid as illustrated by his failure to put India on the red list which allowed thousands to travel to the UK and bring the more virulent Indian iant to Glasgow, thus making it much more dficult to reopen hospitality venues and football stadiums.If Glasgow has to suffer further or extended restrictions thanks to the selfish actions of those Rangers supporters in George Square, then itrsquos guaranteed Mr Wilson will blame the SNP.Mary Thomas, Edinburgh.CELEBRATIONS WITHOUT THE BILETHE headline over Brian Wilsons article states that the "SNP ... guaranteed George Square chaos". Younger readers may not be aware of Mr Wilsons long history of visceral opposition to Scottish independence. Does he believe that the poisonous tribalism which afflicts our society in the West of Scotland and beyond and which sustains the dominance of the "Old Firm" over Scottish football is attributable in whole or in part to the SNP It may have escaped the notice of Mr Wilson and many others that the championships of SPFL League  and League  in  were also won by Glasgow teams. The smaller and more local tribes which support Partick Thistle and Queens Park were equally joyful and held celebrations which attracted little or no media attention.Willie Maclean, Milngavie.WAS THERE UNITY IN A COMMON CAUSE NEIL Mackay claims that "sectarianism shows a Scottish face to the world" .As is understood, the tribal Rangers Celtic Protestant Catholic ide arose from immigration in previous centuries.It is to be hoped that sectarianism in the west of Scotland gathers less publicity when the world looks at Pollokshields and the strong public intervention to stop brutal dawn raids on two immigrants who were from a country far away.It would be interesting to knowthat gathering included many Rangers and Celtic supporters united in that effort to prevent the immigrantsrsquo deportation. Or in the same George Square on Sunday after the Rangers mayhem in the previous hours, who knowsthose united at the peaceful rally for Palestinians from another country far away from Scotland included Rangers and Celtic supporters protesting in that common cause Maybe any future humanitarian-type protestations could show a representation of peaceful Rangers and Celtic supporters in their colours to show the world that the destructive face of sectarianism is promoted only by a flawed section of small-minded people who are outnumbered by the big-hearted people of Scotland. This may help discard bigotry and prejudice as all come together to promote a better face to the world of concern and kindness to the desperate and the downtrodden.Irene Munro, Conon Bridge.CAUSE FOR DISMAY AND CONCERNWE would need to have a heart of stone not to have been moved by the words of Canon Matt McManus . Here we have a man who has clearly spent his le in works for the public good feeling that he has to write such words in disbelief, bewilderment and, perhaps, even despair at the hatred generated toward him in certain quarters.While his sense of dismay will have moved our hearts, it should also be recording concern in our minds. Yes, concern in our minds because we live in a country where such awful behaviour can still arise. No doubt the many true friends of Canon McManus, to whom he refers, will be confirming to him that his many years of work and service are truly valued and appreciated.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.CHALLENGE UNJUST LAWS IN COURTIF "the law of the land should not be sovereign over the will of the people" as suggested by David Gray , then who rules  The answer is simply anarchy.If any law is perceived to be so onerous or unjust the answer is clear: it can be challenged in court and changed by Parliament.This Mr Gray acknowledges in the case of suffragettes .There were many residents in Pollokshields who were not best pleased by the antics of those who chanted and shouted their opposition to the legal removal of two illegal immigrants, especially on the grounds that the timings were religiously inauspicious, that is, the end of Ramadan and the beginning of the Festival of Eid. It transpired that they were not of the Islamic faith, rather Sikhism. Im not convinced that the deeds of the Pollokshields protestors could be labelled "kindly motivated actions" by lying under a vehicle and blocking the police.Robin Johnston, Newton Mearns.SWINNEY OFF TO A BAD STARTAS always the news on your front page this morning makes interesting reading. John Swinney has been moved from his outstanding successin education, to deal with the current Covid situation, which as we know is causing much worry and distress .Having overseen the continuous fall in education standards in Scotland since he became Education Secretary in , what have we to look forward to in the coming days and months with regards to Mr Swinneys dabbling with Covid  He hasnt started well, of course, stating that the "silence from Rangers was deafening as fans gathered last Saturday" ndash as was his, the First Ministers and Humza Yousafs deafening silence about the congregation of hundreds of protesters in Pollokshields last Thursday, the thousands demonstrating in George Square during the Palestinian Support Rally last Sunday and the thousands demonstrating outside the BBC headquarters in Glasgow on the same day. Selective Covid restrictions being enforced would appear to be the name of the game under the new SNP regime.I presume, too, that Mr Swinney will replace the First Minister at her daily and or regular TV news updates re Covid  That must be a dficult decision for the humble Ms Sturgeon to make ndash what on earth will she be concentrating her efforts on  Let me guess.Walter Paul, Glasgow.Read more: I have sought to do good for  years. Why do they hate me

title: iain-macwhirter-nicola-sturgeons-cabinet-reshuffle-recycle
story: Not so much a reshuffle as a retread.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos latest and most extensive reshuffle was somewhat underwhelming. Not so much a reshuffle as a recycle, with old faces like Shona Robison, a former undistinguished health secretary back in at social justice Keith Brown another ex-sacked minister is back in as justice secretary - potentially a highly sensitive role given the deepening Crown Office crisis over the now pound million bill for malicious prosecutions in the Rangers case.
